prompt: You 've finally managed to discover the secret to immortality . Suddenly , Death appears before you , hands you a business card , and says , `` When you realize living forever sucks , call this number , I 've got a job offer for you . ''
story: I sat nervously in the room , draped almost all in black , mindlessly tapping my fingers to pass the time . From the outside , the building looked like any other office tower . Glass panels lined the entire structure , a polished lobby with two receptionists dressed in blazer and white buttoned up shirt . <newline> <newline> My ripped jeans and worn out t-shirt must have looked terribly out of place , in contrast with the neat and pristine condition of the building . But then again , when you 're someone who has been living for the past one thousand years , without any way to die no matter how you tried , looks is n't exactly a high priority . <newline> <newline> `` The boss is ready to see you now , '' a voice interrupted my thoughts . I turned to see a woman standing next to the hallway . She was wearing the same outfit as the receptionists downstairs , the blazer and shirt hugging her slim figure tightly . I may have walked the earth for a thousand years , but rarely have I seen such specimen of beauty . The boss of this place must have some exquisite taste . <newline> <newline> `` Ugh okay , '' I said and headed to the direction she was pointing . It was a short hallway with a grand wooden door at end . My thoughts flashed back to a thousand years ago , when I first saw ... HIM . Draped in black robes that flowed strangely in the wind , it was quite easy to identify who he was . The feared angel of Death . He approached me as I was walking down the bazaar street , the first day after I had achieved my gift . Or curse , as how I would see it today . <newline> <newline> He told me that he had a job for me , asked whether I was interested . I simply brushed him away , of course . Why would an immortal want a job with Death ? He simply laughed at me , and proclaimed that there would be a day when I would beg him for a job . <newline> <newline> The second time he appeared to me was five hundred years after the first encounter . In my bedroom in medieval Europe , after a drunken orgy with the finest courtesans the Portugal king had to offer . <newline> <newline> `` NOT BORED YET ? '' he simply asked , telling me that the job offer was still open . I brushed him off again , saying that I would never want his job , or any job for related to him for that matter . <newline> <newline> And yet five hundred years later , I was seated in front of him , in a posh office that sat on the highest story of downtown Manhattan . I wanted out . I was bored . I no longer wanted to live forever . And Death seemed to offer the only viable option . <newline> <newline> `` What job do you have for me ? '' was my first question as soon as I sat down on the chair opposite of him . There was a raspy sound beneath the shadows of his hood , like someone who was drawing their last few breaths . A sound that I was all too familiar with . <newline> <newline> Death leaned closer to the table , crossing his fingers in front of him . Skin were peeling off some of them , while others were only bones . <newline> <newline> `` DO YOU DESIRE DEATH ? '' his voice croaked , filling the room with despair . <newline> <newline> `` Yes , if I do n't I wo n't be here in the first place . '' <newline> <newline> `` GOOD ... '' Death replied , and he flew out of his chair , straight at me . There was not even time for me to shout . His hands gripped my face , a cold , burning embrace , as my vision blurred and changed . Death was giving me a vision . <newline> <newline> In it I saw a magnificent city perched above the clouds , basking in all the glory and warmth of God . HEAVEN , a voice whispered at the back of my head . <newline> <newline> The vision switched , the wondrous city morphed into a twisting cavern of despair and anguish , filled with tortured souls that were damned to eternity . HELL , the voice whispered now . <newline> <newline> AND WE 'RE GOING TO TAKE THEM ALL , the voice announced , as it flashed to the image of hundreds of people , all around the world . They all looked normal , except that they were not . All of them were like me , immortals . People who could never die , who could never enter hell nor heaven . <newline> <newline> In that moment I understood . Death was raising an army to take over the afterlife . And he needed those who could never die . <newline> <newline> `` I 'm in , '' I announced as my vision cleared back to normal , revealing the office that I was seated in . Perhaps this would be the salvation that I was seeking for . <newline> <newline> -- -- -- -- -- - <newline> <newline> /r/dori_tales

prompt: You 've finally managed to discover the secret to immortality . Suddenly , Death appears before you , hands you a business card , and says , `` When you realize living forever sucks , call this number , I 've got a job offer for you . ''
story:
As I stood in the dimly lit laboratory, surrounded by the faint scent of disinfectant and the soft hum of machinery, I felt an overwhelming sense of elation. The years of tireless research, the countless setbacks, and the unwavering dedication had finally paid off. I held in my hands the vial of liquid gold, the key to unlocking the secret of immortality. The implications were staggering – no more disease, no more pain, no more fear of mortality.

I took a deep breath, feeling the weight of my discovery settle upon me like a mantle. I thought of all the loved ones I would never have to say goodbye to, all the experiences I would never have to miss out on. The possibilities were endless, and I felt like I was on the cusp of something truly revolutionary.

Just as I was about to make the first injection, a figure materialized before me. Death, the embodiment of mortality, stood tall and imposing, his presence both captivating and unsettling. He wore a tailored black suit, complete with a crisp white shirt and a black tie, and carried a small leather briefcase in one hand.

"Congratulations," he said, his voice low and gravelly. "You've managed to cheat fate. But let me ask you, have you ever stopped to consider the consequences?"

I felt a shiver run down my spine as he handed me a small business card. It was a standard issue, with my name and title printed in bold letters, but there was something unsettling about the way it felt in my hand.

"When you realize living forever sucks," Death said, his eyes glinting with a hint of mischief, "call this number. I've got a job offer for you."

I stared at the card, feeling a sense of trepidation wash over me. What could this job possibly entail? And why would Death, the personification of mortality, be offering me a position?

As I looked up at Death, I saw a glimmer of something almost like amusement in his eyes. "You see, immortality isn't all it's cracked up to be," he said. "There's a certain... ennui that comes with living forever. The excitement wears off, the novelty wears off, and you're left with nothing but the same old routine day in and day out."

I felt a pang of uncertainty, a sense that I had been blinded by my own ambition. Could it be true? Was living forever really just a never-ending cycle of boredom and tedium?

Death's eyes seemed to bore into my soul, as if he could see the doubts that were swirling inside me. "But don't worry," he said, his voice dripping with sarcasm. "I've got a solution for that. And it's not as boring as it sounds."

With that, he turned and disappeared into thin air, leaving me to ponder the implications of his offer. I looked down at the business card, feeling a sense of trepidation mixed with curiosity. What lay ahead? And was I ready to take the leap?

prompt: The moon is actually a giant egg , and it has just started to hatch .
story: Sadie 's window was n't very large , no more than a hand mirror sized piece of glass set into the steel wall right by her bed , bordered with a serious looking rim of extra metal to ensure that nothing and nobody was going to mess with it . Depressurization was no joke , and did n't Sadie know it with every grownup telling her at least three times a day . The glass was very cold all the time , and if Sadie breathed on it then a heavy mist coalesced on the pane and obscured the barren landscape until she rubbed it away with her fingers . She did this , breathing and wiping , a lot at night when she could n't sleep , especially when Earth was in view outside her window . Breathe , and make the blue dot vanish in a wash of soft-focus , then wipe and bring it back , bright as a magic coin in pure black velvet . <newline> <newline> She could see the ground , too , and that was interesting enough as it went . Sadie 's window overlooked a ridge that was set atop a giant crater so she could peer way down into its depths if she angled her head right . The shadows out there were sharp as papercuts , here is sunlight , nearly blinding , and here is shadow , impenetrably black . Some parts of the crater were always in shadow , no matter the angle of the sunlight . Sadie did n't particularly like looking at those , they had the same unknowable quality as the darkness in the crack of a closet door . <newline> <newline> Her favorite nights were the ones when her Daddy had a little extra time on his way back from work . He 'd buzz her mobile and let her know what time to watch her window , and then have his workmates drop him off a ways from the hab so he could take the long way home , right by her window . The first time he 'd done it Sadie had gasped and laughed , watching the tiny man through her tiny window as he bounded in superhuman leaps across the dusty plains . He 'd cavorted , cartwheeling and doing slow-motion flips , bright sunlight leaping off the metal bits of his suit . When he reached the hab he 'd always do the same thing , come right up to her little window and make a heart with his suit 's gloves , then wave and make his way to the airlock . Sadie always pressed her tiny hand to the glass when he did that , no matter how cold it felt . <newline> <newline> He 'd buzzed her earlier that night , the same message as always . <newline> <newline> *Take a look out the porthole and look for the flying fish ! 8PM* <newline> <newline> It was a game of theirs , to pretend the Hab was really a ship on the seas of Earth . They 'd lie side by side in Sadie 's bed and peer out through her 'porthole ' at the impossibly bright stars , making them into deep sea creatures . <newline> <newline> `` See ? An octopus ! '' <newline> <newline> `` Ocopus '' <newline> <newline> `` Ooh , a giant squid ! '' <newline> <newline> `` Gyant Squit '' <newline> <newline> So now it was 8 and Sadie was very comfortable , thank you , cocooned in her special purple blanket with the cartoon octopi swimming across it , googly-eyed and intent on mysterious octopi-business . Earth was n't visible tonight , but she could see all the way into the crater , as deep as it was ever possible to see , only a few pockets of darkness remaining . Everything was still , more still even than a photograph , because this scene held the possibility of change but the knowledge that it would never come . It was a scene frozen in ice , immovable . <newline> <newline> But- what was that ? <newline> <newline> Sadie inched forward in her bed , squinting through the window . A brief movement had shaken the far wall of the crater , some subtle shifting of rock that had caught her eye but was now lost , the static quality of the view undisturbed again . Her eyes searched the wall of the crater , looking for some difference , but she could see nothing . Her heart was beating faster . She knew she was being silly . She was just tired , that was all , tired and excited to see her Daddy . <newline> <newline> And there , out of nowhere , bounding over a far ridge like a spring-loaded action figure , there he was ! Sadie grinned and hugged her blanket to her . Her Daddy was playing around now , pretending to be very clumsy . He leapt over a boulder but caught his toe on it in midair so that he did a slow flip , waving his arms like he had fallen off a diving board . At the last moment he caught himself , landing smoothly . Sadie clapped . <newline> <newline> As though summoned by the sound of her palms , the far wall of the crater split in half . Sadie screamed , covering her mouth with her hands . A giant sliver of rock fell slowly away from the crater wall , crashing to the floor of the depression and splitting into many pieces . Sadie 's eyes flicked to her father . He was still bounding towards her , playing the fool and tumbling here and there over the rubble-strewn landscape . To reach the Hab , he 'd have to skirt the rim of the crater . <newline> <newline> Another section of the crater wall dislodged itself and fell away and ... and something poked out from the now triangular gap in the Moon 's surface . A long ribbed finger of flesh , wet-looking and colored a deep green . It quested in the empty space , twisting this way and that like a blind snake . After a moment it retreated back into the blackness , then , like a sudden waterfall , the entire side of the crater collapsed . Debris showered down into the pit , giant splinters of stone crumbling against one another and dissolving . The dark triangle in the crater wall had turned into an oblong cave mouth , but the angle of the sunlight was such that Sadie 's eyes could not penetrate its darkness . <newline> <newline> She looked for her father again , searching feverishly across the landscape . There ! He was standing stock still , transfixed , directly above the cave mouth on the thin lip of stone that remained of what had been the lip of the crater . He must have been looking down at the still cascading fall of rubble as it settled down to the bottom of the crater . <newline> <newline> Below him , deep in the hole in the Moon 's skin , two emerald green eyes opened . They glowed in the darkness , each vertical pupil the height of an adult man . Two giant hands appeared on either side of the cave , gripping the stone with long fingers bent crazily around several extra sets of knuckles . Slowly , the beast pulled itself forward and pushed its head into the light . <newline> <newline> Sadie screamed again . <newline> <newline> Edit- some words . <newline>

prompt: The moon is actually a giant egg , and it has just started to hatch .
story:
The sky was a deep, foreboding crimson, like the belly of a beast that had swallowed the sun whole. The stars twinkled like ice chips in a forgotten glass, their light refracted through the atmosphere like a thousand tiny prisms. And in the center of it all, the moon hung suspended, a glowing orb that pulsed with an otherworldly energy.

Dr. Elara Vex stood at the edge of the crater, her eyes fixed on the moon's surface. She had spent years studying the lunar anomaly, pouring over data and running simulations, but nothing could have prepared her for this. The moon was... shifting. Its surface was rippling, like the skin of a living creature.

As she watched, a tendril of light burst forth from the moon's equator, stretching towards the Earth like a tentative finger. Elara's heart skipped a beat. This was it. This was the moment she had been waiting for.

The light grew brighter, illuminating the dark expanse of space. Elara felt a shiver run down her spine as she realized that the moon was not just hatching – it was unfolding. The surface was unfolding, like the pages of a great, cosmic book.

The light coalesced into a brilliant, silver-white shape, which began to take on a life of its own. It pulsed and throbbed, like a heartbeat, and Elara felt her own pulse quicken in response. The shape grew larger, more defined, until it was a great, glowing sphere that hovered in the darkness.

And then, in an instant, it was open. The moon's surface split apart, revealing a vast, cavernous interior. Elara felt a rush of wind, like the breath of a giant, as the moon's contents spilled out into space.

A creature emerged, its form indescribable. It was like nothing Elara had ever seen – a mass of writhing, pulsing tendrils, with eyes that burned like stars. The creature was enormous, its body stretching across the sky like a living, breathing shadow.

As Elara watched, the creature began to move, its tendrils stretching out like ghostly fingers. It was heading straight for the Earth, and Elara felt a sense of wonder, of awe, that she had never felt before.

The creature's eyes locked onto hers, and Elara felt a jolt of electricity run through her body. She was being drawn into the creature's gaze, into its very soul. And in that moment, she knew that her life would never be the same again.

The creature's tendrils reached out, touching Elara's face. She felt a surge of energy, like a flood of knowledge and emotion. And then, in an instant, everything went black.

When Elara came to, she was lying on the ground, her head throbbing with a dull, pulsing pain. The moon was still open, its contents still spilling out into space. But the creature was gone, vanished into the depths of the lunar cavity.

Elara stumbled to her feet, her eyes fixed on the moon's surface. She knew that she had been changed, that she had been touched by something greater than herself. And as she looked up at the moon, she felt a sense of wonder, of awe, that she had never felt before.

The moon was not just a giant egg – it was a doorway, a portal to a world beyond our own. And Elara knew that she would never be the same again.

prompt: For years in your youth the same imaginary character appears in your dreams , you are good friends . Years later , when adult , you meet her in real life , she clearly recognises you and tries to avoid you , and you want answers .
story: “ No , no no no ... ” She backed up and turned the other way the second she saw me heading towards her . <newline> <newline> “ Hey ! ” Starting to walk quickly now I picked up my pace until I nearly ran into her . She tried to duck behind one of the men carrying samples around the food court but instead just managed an awkward half step around him before I grabbed her shoulder . She turned towards me so I could get a clear view of her face . Now I was sure it was her . “ Joanne ? ” Her eyes lit up , if only for a second before she turned back around , grabbed her hands and lowered her head before once again repeating her rant of no ’ s from earlier . <newline> <newline> “ You can ’ t be here , not now . I finally get this far and now you ’ re here. ” She was mumbling more to herself than to me at this point . <newline> <newline> “ You… you ’ re real , ” I said , looking back to her eyes . “ How… do you know who I am ? ” <newline> <newline> “ I ’ m real ? Of course I ’ m real ! But you can ’ t be here ! ” Now she was talking directly to me . “ Do you know what kinds of hell you put me through ? The amount of bullying , stress , and endless therapy ! Dave , I finally get rid of you and now you have to come back in my head and tear it back out from under me , ” she slapped her head a few times as she delivered the last line . <newline> <newline> “ What are you talking about ? I- ” <newline> <newline> “ We were best friends , true or false ? ” She asked . <newline> <newline> “ True , no false , I mean , we were friends but not… ” I looked at her once more to make sure she was actually standing there . “ You ’ re a dream , ” She froze at this . <newline> <newline> “ No , no I ’ m- you ’ re a hallucination . I saw you for years ! Every waking moment from- ” <newline> <newline> “ Seven until twelve ” I looked at her shaking my head , incredulous to what was happening . <newline> <newline> “ When we fell out of that tree that one summer , ” she smiled for just a second before frowning again and looking down . <newline> <newline> “ But that was just a dream , I woke up right after that. ” <newline> <newline> “ No , that actually happened . I was awake , I remember it exactly because that ’ s when I still lived in Australia with my parents. ” I looked at her , and began to realize something . <newline> <newline> “ You saw me when you were awake , I dreamt you while I was asleep . I lived in Boston , when you lived in Australia. ” <newline> <newline> “ Hold on , ” She sat down . “ My head hurts , ” She paused . “ We met , every day- ” <newline> “ Night , ” I corrected . She looked at me and scowled . <newline> <newline> “ Every day . For five years , until we fell . What happened after that ? ” <newline> <newline> “ I told you , I woke up. ” <newline> <newline> “ No , what happened for me ? I don ’ t remember anything but falling head first and then… ” <newline> <newline> “ Joanne , ” I looked her straight in the eyes this time . “ I woke up. ” <newline>

prompt: For years in your youth the same imaginary character appears in your dreams , you are good friends . Years later , when adult , you meet her in real life , she clearly recognises you and tries to avoid you , and you want answers .
story:
The city streets blurred together like watercolors in the rain, each face a fleeting splash of color before disappearing into the crowd. I navigated the throngs with a practiced air, my eyes scanning the sidewalks for a glimpse of familiarity. It was a habit I'd developed over the years, ever since the dream had started.

In my youth, I'd been obsessed with a character named Luna. She was a wispy, ethereal thing, with hair like starlight and eyes that shone like moonstones. We'd dance through dreams together, our footsteps weaving a rhythm that only we could hear. I'd confided in her, shared my deepest fears and desires, and she'd listened with a sympathetic ear. She was my confidante, my partner in crime, my best friend.

But as I grew older, the dreams began to fade. I'd wake up with a start, feeling a pang of loss, and wonder if I'd just imagined the whole thing. It wasn't until I was in my mid-twenties, wandering the streets of Tokyo, that I saw her again. Luna stood on the corner of a narrow alley, her eyes locked on mine with a mixture of recognition and wariness.

For a moment, we just stared at each other, the city around us melting away. I felt a jolt of excitement, mixed with a dash of trepidation. What was she doing here? Why was she avoiding me?

I took a step forward, my heart pounding in my chest. Luna's eyes darted around the alley, as if searching for an escape route. I followed her gaze, but there was no one there. She was alone, and yet, she seemed to be surrounded by a palpable sense of unease.

"Hey," I said, my voice barely above a whisper. "It's me. We've known each other for years."

Luna's eyes snapped back to mine, and for a moment, I saw a glimmer of the old Luna, the one who'd danced with me through dreams and shared my deepest secrets. But it was quickly replaced by a mask of caution, a sense of being trapped in a situation she didn't want to be in.

"I...I don't know what you're talking about," she stammered, her voice trembling.

I took another step forward, my eyes locked on hers. "Don't lie to me, Luna. I know you. We've been friends for years, in dreams and in my heart."

Luna's eyes darted around the alley again, this time with a sense of desperation. She knew I was right, but she was scared of what that meant. What did it mean, that I'd found her in the real world?

I reached out a hand, hesitantly, and Luna flinched, as if I'd touched a live wire. But I didn't pull back. I wanted to know what had happened to her, what had brought her to this place.

"Luna, please," I said, my voice softening. "Tell me what's going on. What's happening to you?"

For a moment, I thought I saw a glimmer of the old Luna, the one who'd listened to my secrets and shared her own. But it was just a trick of the light, a fleeting moment of connection in a sea of uncertainty.

Luna turned and ran, disappearing into the crowded streets of Tokyo. I watched her go, feeling a sense of loss, mixed with a sense of determination. I'd find her, I'd get answers, and I'd uncover the truth about our strange, twisted friendship.

My copilot can handle this . <newline> <newline> 10.05 : What a pleasant nap . Still I ca n't shake the feeling that God was warning me of something . God has never steered me wrong before . prompt: You glance at your watch 10:34 am , roughly 10 seconds later your plane explodes over the Pacific Ocean . Your eyes open as you jolt awake . The familiar hum of the planes engine remains . Checking your watch it is 9:35
story:
The soft glow of the dashboard lights illuminated the contours of your face, a map of exhaustion etched into the skin. Your eyes, heavy with the weight of a thousand midnights, slowly creaked open, like the hinges of a rusty gate. The hum of the engine, a constant companion on this journey, vibrated through the air, a reassuring thrum that seemed to pulse in time with your own ragged breathing.

As you sat up, the familiar contours of the seatbelt dug into your shoulders, a gentle reminder of the fragile hold you had on reality. Your gaze drifted to the watch, a sleek, silver band that seemed to mock you with its precision. 10:34. The numbers blurred together, a maddening dance of digits that refused to coalesce into a coherent thought.

And then, in an instant, the world around you erupted into chaos. The plane shuddered, a violent lurch that sent your stomach plummeting into your chest. The hum of the engine grew louder, a deafening roar that seemed to split the air apart. The windows, once a serene expanse of blue, shattered into a thousand shards of glass, like the fragile skin of a butterfly.

You felt yourself lifted out of your seat, a weightless sensation that defied the laws of physics. The world around you dissolved into a kaleidoscope of color and sound, a maelstrom of terror that threatened to consume you whole. And then, in an instant, it was over. The plane, a burning, twisted wreck, plummeted into the depths of the Pacific, leaving behind a trail of smoke and debris that seemed to stretch on forever.

You jolted awake, your heart racing like a jackrabbit on a pogo stick. The hum of the engine, once a reassuring presence, now seemed like a cruel joke, a reminder of the fragility of life. You sat up, your eyes scanning the cabin, searching for some sign of what had just happened. The seats, once a comfortable haven, now seemed like a cold, unforgiving slab of metal.

You glanced at your watch, a desperate bid for sanity in a world gone mad. 9:35. The numbers seemed to mock you, a cruel reminder of the time that had slipped away, like sand between your fingers. You felt a wave of panic wash over you, a primal fear that threatened to consume you whole.

As you stumbled out of the wreckage, the bright sunlight seemed to blind you, a harsh, unforgiving glare that cut through the haze of your mind. You stumbled, your legs trembling like a leaf, as you struggled to make sense of the world around you. The plane, a twisted, burning wreck, seemed to loom over you, a monolith of destruction that seemed to mock your very existence.

And yet, even in the midst of chaos, you felt a strange sense of calm, a sense of acceptance that seemed to wash over you like a cool, clear stream. It was as if, in the face of such unimaginable destruction, you had been given a rare gift – a chance to start anew, to rebuild and rediscover the world around you. The question, of course, was whether you had the strength to do so.

prompt: You live in a world where there has never been sickness , and you are the first to have ever experienced being sick .
story: I open my eyes in a panic , sweat beading and then falling down my face . I look around and the sun in shining through the maroon curtains of my studio apartment . Everything seems to be as I left it the afternoon before , but there is a heavy , unfamiliar air in the room . I notice the throw cover I lazily hang to separate my twin size bed from the rest of the apartment has been ripped to the ground , and that the kitchen faucet rhythmically drips against the cold steel sink . I was alone last night like I always am , I think . No one has been here but me in over three months . <newline> <newline> I 'm not allowed to think about it much longer , as the feeling in my stomach bubbles over and pops once more as it had been doing all night , slowly worsening . I pinch my eyes shut , knowing what 's coming next , and for just one moment , as the pain peaks like a giant wave waiting to break , I think I may just die this time . And just as quickly , the wave reaches the shore , and I know I have a few moments of peace . I open my eyes and look around . I ca n't help but surrender to the weight of them after a few moments , and I drift to an uneasy sleep , as the tension escapes from my stomach and from the rest of my body , dissipating into the small space I call home . <newline> <newline> The next wave takes what remains in me and decimates it . The pain blinds me , numbing me to all feeling and sensation . The relief never comes as I close my eyes involuntarily . <newline> <newline> I finally come to and realize I had been asleep for a while . I open my eyes and , fighting the blinding lights and white room , I see that the natural maroon lighting of my apartment has been replaced by white hospital lights . Beyond the thick glass walls of the room that was smaller than my apartment - though I did n't think it got smaller than that - stand people I have never seen before , looking at papers and analyzing the rhythms of the machines I now realize I am hooked up to . The men all stop and slowly turn their unexpected gazes at me as I begin to curl my sore body into a seated position , only to be shocked back down by a face that made the sea of unfamiliar faces fade away . <newline> <newline> The prominent cheekbones that made my mother seem so much prouder than her nature would actually allow remained strong , though the rest of her seemed to be worn down by the years . The same mahogany curls fell across those cheeks and down right above her shoulders , though they seemed more ashen now . Her frail yet determined hand touching the impenetrable glass and reaching to pick me up and hold me , and I recall the day in my childhood where , in my insistence to become a world champion roller bladder , I fell and scrapped my knee . And I recall the comforted feeling of being cradled in her arms in fetal position . And I recall never wanting to leave the warmth of the embrace . <newline> <newline> And just as I begin to reach out , I crouch and close my eyes to the familiar feeling that boils over in my stomach . Falling in and out of consciousness , I see quick flashes . I see my mother 's crystal blue eyes well with tears that could not be held . I see her strong posture and I see the unfamiliar men gather , bowing and shaking their heads , unsure . I see the green lines of the machines jump and dance . And I see a sign , sloppily and quickly written above my bed , the only writing visible to me in my haze . It read `` Patient Zero '' .

prompt: You live in a world where there has never been sickness , and you are the first to have ever experienced being sick .
story:
I woke up to a world that was both familiar and foreign. The sunlight streaming through the windows was the same warm, golden hue it had been for as long as I could remember. The air was crisp and clean, with a hint of the sweet scent of blooming flowers. But something was off. A dull ache had settled in the pit of my stomach, like a stone slowly sinking into the depths of my belly.

At first, I thought it was just a minor stomach bug, something I could shake off with a few cups of tea and a day of rest. But as the hours ticked by, the ache only grew stronger, spreading its tendrils to my limbs and my head. I felt like I was drowning in a sea of fatigue, unable to catch my breath or lift my eyes.

I stumbled out of bed, my legs trembling beneath me like a newborn fawn taking its first steps. My mother, who had always been the epitome of health and vitality, looked at me with concern etched on her face. "What's wrong, child?" she asked, her voice laced with a mixture of worry and confusion.

I tried to explain, but the words caught in my throat like a bird with a broken wing. I couldn't describe the way my body felt, the way my skin prickled with a thousand tiny needles, or the way my mind fogged over like a mirror left in a steam room. All I could do was point to my body and say, "I'm sick."

The concept was foreign to her, to us all. We had never known sickness, never known the feeling of being vulnerable to the whims of our bodies. We had always been strong, resilient, and healthy. The idea that I, the first of our generation, was now experiencing the opposite was both fascinating and terrifying.

As the day wore on, I began to feel like a stranger in my own skin. My mother took me to see the village healer, a wise and kind woman named Akira who had spent her life studying the ancient art of medicine. But even Akira's skilled hands couldn't quite grasp the nature of my affliction.

"It's not a poison, child," she said, her eyes scanning my body with a mixture of curiosity and concern. "It's not a curse. It's just...your body is trying to tell you something."

I didn't know what to make of her words. I just knew that I felt like I was losing myself, like my body was betraying me in ways I couldn't understand. As the sun dipped below the horizon, casting the world in a warm, golden light, I felt a sense of desperation creeping in. I was the first, the only one who had ever known sickness. And I wasn't sure if I would ever be the same again.

As I lay in bed that night, my body wracked with pain and my mind foggy with confusion, I couldn't help but wonder what the future held. Would I be able to find a way to heal, to overcome this strange and foreign affliction? Or would I be forever changed, a stranger in a world that had never known sickness? Only time would tell.

prompt: You are at the park with your kids , when you see the telltale signs of a lightning strike . You divert your kids from danger , but are hit by lightning . Soon after , you discover that your Dad Senses have increased 100 fold .
story: <newline> After the strike , the first sign was the food . For some reason , food that I had been saving started going missing . A cupcake from the nice store down the street vanished . The chocolate chips vanished into the night . My boxes of cereal were emptied , and the boxes replaced on the shelf . <newline> <newline> It was clear who the culprit was . <newline> <newline> “ Dad ! ” I cried out , catching him eating my last Poptart as a midnight snack . <newline> <newline> “ What ? Oh , were you saving this ? I ’ m so sorry , Jess , I ’ ll pick up some more from the store tomorrow. ” <newline> <newline> “ Daaad ! ” I wailed , “ That Poptart was for breakfast tomorrow and now I ’ ll have to go to school hungry and everyone will think I ’ m crazy because I get angry when I ’ m hungry ! ” <newline> <newline> “ Honey , I ’ m sorry ! I ’ m just hungry all the time these days , it ’ s so odd ! ” He narrowed his eyes at the pastry . “ I honestly don ’ t even like poptarts usually . Don ’ t know why I took it. ” <newline> <newline> “ Whatever , dad. ” I sighed and rolled my eyes . “ When child protective services calls for starving your child I won ’ t cover your ass. ” I called out as I headed back up to my room . <newline> <newline> “ Don ’ t say ass , young lady ! And where did all that attitude come from ? You ’ re a middle class thirteen year old , not a jaded punk rocker ! ” <newline> <newline> Suddenly , my previously lame single dad , who hadn ’ t been home for dinner in over a year , had time to make meals ( sometimes amazing , sometimes so bad that they set off the smoke alarm , but never the mediocre box macaroni from before the lightning ) , come to my soccer games ( and get kicked out of my soccer games for being too rowdy by far ) , check my homework with me , and relentlessly mock Dance Moms when I tried to watch it . And the puns , dear God , the puns were terrible . <newline> But I ’ ll take it all , because I ’ d been putting up with the shit I was taking from Jim and his friends for months when he finally pushed me over the edge . I was just trying to mind my own business , really , but I dropped my notebook in the hall , and when I heard the wolf whistles as I stood up I saw red . <newline> <newline> Watching my dad come into the principal ’ s office as Jim moaned and held his gory nose I thought I was done for . <newline> <newline> He followed the principal into the back , giving me a hard eye as he was dragged away to hear of my newfound proclivity to violence . <newline> <newline> When he came out he stood over me , staring me down . I hung my head . Out of the corner of my eye I could see Jim smile through the hand he was holding over his nose . <newline> <newline> “ Jess . What happened ? ” He glared down at me . <newline> <newline> “ Well… ah… ” The principal looked on in concern . <newline> <newline> “ I dropped my notebook , and when I bent over to pick it up , Jim whistled. ” I said softly . <newline> <newline> “ I see . So you hauled off and broke his nose , is that correct ? ” His tone was sterner than I ’ d ever heard it . <newline> <newline> “ Yes.. ” I whispered . I could feel my shame flooding my body . <newline> <newline> “ I see. ” He said again . “ Well , Jim , I would normally be suing for sexual harassment , but seeing as my daughter here broke your nose in front of half your class , maybe we should call it even , huh ? If you plan to do it again , though , I would advise lawyering up first . Principal Rodgers , Jess is taking the day off . When she returns on Monday I expect proof of a safe schooling environment for her and all the girls at this school , or the superintendent will be hearing that you intended to suspend my daughter for defending herself against a perceived threat of sexual harassment . Clear ? ” <newline> <newline> I stared at him in shock as the principal nodded . <newline> <newline> On the way out , he leaned down to whisper to me . <newline> <newline> “ I saw the security footage . It was a nice right hook , but I don ’ t think it was one of your greatest hits. ” And I giggled . <newline>

prompt: You are at the park with your kids , when you see the telltale signs of a lightning strike . You divert your kids from danger , but are hit by lightning . Soon after , you discover that your Dad Senses have increased 100 fold .
story:
The sun beat down on the park, casting a warm glow over the swings and slides. My children, Jack and Lily, chased each other around the playground, their laughter carrying on the breeze. I sat on a bench, watching them with a mix of exhaustion and pride. My wife, Sarah, sat beside me, her eyes fixed on the children as she expertly juggled a picnic blanket and a thermos of iced tea.

As we sat there, the air began to shift. The sky darkened, and the wind picked up. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I noticed the telltale signs of a lightning strike: the electric scent of ozone, the way the air seemed to vibrate with tension. I quickly scanned the playground, my eyes locking onto the children as they played oblivious to the danger.

"Kids, come here!" I shouted, my voice carrying above the din of the playground. They stopped mid-play, their faces upturned as they looked at me. I grabbed their hands, pulling them close as I stood up. "Let's go find a safe place."

We made a dash for the picnic area, the children's eyes wide with excitement. But I was focused on getting them to safety. I didn't notice the bolt of lightning that struck the ground mere feet away. It was a searing pain, a blast of heat that seemed to rip through my body. I felt myself lifted off the ground, my vision blurring as I was consumed by a brilliant light.

When the light faded, I was lying on the grass, my head throbbing. The children were huddled beside me, their faces etched with worry. Sarah was kneeling beside me, her eyes filled with tears.

"Mom?" I croaked, my voice barely audible. "Where's Mom?"

Sarah's face crumpled, and she buried her face in her hands. "I...I don't know," she stammered. "I was just...I was just getting the kids to safety."

I tried to sit up, but a wave of dizziness washed over me. I collapsed back onto the grass, my eyes scanning the playground. The children were staring at me, their faces pale.

As I lay there, I began to feel...different. My senses were heightened, as if I could feel the world around me in a way I never had before. The air was thick with scents, the sounds of the playground amplified to a deafening level. I could feel the vibrations of the earth beneath me, the thrum of the children's laughter and the beat of their hearts.

It was as if my senses had been turned up to 100, and I was drowning in a sea of sensory input. I felt like I was seeing the world for the first time, like I was experiencing it in a way that was both exhilarating and terrifying.

As I lay there, I realized that I had been given a gift – or a curse. I was no longer just a father, a husband, a person. I was something more. Something...electric.

The children's voices faded into the background as I focused on the world around me. I felt a sense of wonder, of awe, that I had never felt before. And I knew that nothing would ever be the same again.

prompt: Write a horror story from the perspective of the antagonist . Make them as sympathetic as possible .
story: O Me ! O Life ! <newline> <newline> <newline> O ME ! O life ! ... of the questions of these recurring ; <newline> Of the endless trains of the faithless—of cities fill ’ d with the foolish ; <newline> Of myself forever reproaching myself , ( for who more foolish than I , and who more faithless ? ) <newline> Of eyes that vainly crave the light—of the objects mean—of the struggle ever renew ’ d ; <newline> Of the poor results of all—of the plodding and sordid crowds I see around me ; <newline> Of the empty and useless years of the rest—with the rest me intertwined ; <newline> The question , O me ! so sad , recurring—What good amid these , O me , O life ? <newline> <newline> Answer . <newline> <newline> That you are here—that life exists , and identity ; <newline> That the powerful play goes on , and you will contribute a verse . <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> Oh Walty ... .waltywaltywalty . How right he was . See dear reader ... .if you are reading this . You have found this hidden among the garbage and filth , like a flower in the dump . A flower I planted . Old Walt was wrong on one point . Life is n't just a play ! It 's the only play ! The greatest play ! A play where there are no second takes ! Never ending ! Constantly evolving ! A play that has no script but only improvised ... which makes the play a comedy in it 's basest form . A play where emotions are heightened to a point where they vibrate through our bodies like we are stings on a Stradivarius . Enrapturing movements of ecstasy ! The drawn out notes of sorrow , that never seem to end . As if the bow that drags on the strings is never ending . Imagine..a stage that all this takes place on . A stage set as a city . A old city , a city that has fallen and risen like a phoenix over and over again . A city were the good fall , the evil become redeemed . Empires rise and fall . A city where the shadows hide champions and horrors to come . The same shadows hide the nightmare and dreams of the past . All these events powered by the characters on the stage . The deformed that could n't find acceptance but took it in a effort to regain what was lost from their family . The broken rogue thief that has a sense of justice but ca n't conform to the ideas that surround the concept . The inquisitor , driven by the never ending questions to everything and desperately seeks answers from those he deems worthy . The femme fatale warped by love , who just wants to laugh but is tortured for it . The jester ... ..ah yes the jester . The lowly , the important . The canary in the coal mine , the mirror of the kingdom that shows only the true reflection of all things . The one with the burden of laughter . For if he does n't and make others laugh ... .well , then ... only sorrow remains . Every play needs a center figure , a tie that binds , a black hole . A black hole whose gravity everything revolves around and if they are not careful , could be sucked in and never escape ... except through death . This play has that figure , as all good plays do . A dark figure who fights so the sun of hope can shine just for one more second than it did the day before . A figure who has lost far more than they will ever gain . The city in the figure 's gravitational pull , becomes one . And when the sun of hope sets and looks as if it will never return , the city mourns . Dread and fear gain weight and make the air thicker with their pressure ... ..until the figure becomes victorious ! And the release of the pressure becomes sanctified rapture , and all the darkness is washed away in a cathartic tsunami . Hope fills the hearts of the mightiest to the smallest common man , who happens to hold something , like a piece of paper that is covered in hallucinogenic poison that will kill them in hours after they see the comedy in the play and laugh . Or not . <newline> <newline> You see dear reader . Life is a play , not the prison it is for most . A prison that is two dimensional and in black in white . A prison where every day is the same script over and over again . Is n't a tapestry more beautiful when there are more colors ? Is n't a symphony concert more beautiful with more notes ? This play called life is the same . It becomes more beautiful with each verse . With each actor . When old Walty said `` You may contribute a verse . '' It was n't a invitation . It was a commandment . Like when royalty would give commandments to the unwashed by saying `` You may leave . You may live . '' So dear reader ... ..you may contribute a verse . You may contribute a verse NOW ! <newline> HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA

prompt: Write a horror story from the perspective of the antagonist . Make them as sympathetic as possible .
story:
I stood at the edge of the forest, the trees looming above me like skeletal fingers. The wind whispered secrets in my ear, and I felt the familiar tingle of anticipation. It was a sensation I'd grown accustomed to over the years, a reminder that I was needed.

My name is Emilia, and I'm the one they call the Shadow Weaver. I've been tasked with maintaining the delicate balance of the forest's ecosystem, ensuring that the natural order is preserved. It's a duty I take seriously, one that requires great sacrifice.

As I stepped into the trees, the rustling of leaves and snapping of twigs beneath my feet served as a reminder of the world's fragility. I've seen it all before, the beauty and the decay, the life and the death. It's a never-ending cycle, one that I'm bound to perpetuate.

I've been watching the humans for some time now, studying their behavior and learning their patterns. They're a curious species, always seeking to exploit and dominate. But I've seen the damage they can do, the destruction they can unleash. And I've taken it upon myself to put a stop to it.

My methods may seem cruel to some, but I assure you, they're necessary. I've seen the forest's inhabitants suffer at the hands of these careless humans. The trees are dying, the animals are fleeing, and the very fabric of the ecosystem is unraveling. It's a catastrophe, one that I'm determined to prevent.

As I weave my way through the forest, I notice the subtle changes in the environment. A tree's bark is scratched, a bird's nest is disturbed, and a rabbit's tracks are erased. It's all part of my work, a constant reminder of the world's fragility.

I've tried to communicate with the humans, to warn them of the dangers they pose. But they never listen. They just keep coming, driven by their insatiable hunger for resources and their disregard for the consequences. It's a never-ending battle, one that I'm forced to fight alone.

I've seen the fear in their eyes, the terror that grips their hearts when they realize they're not alone. And I've felt it too, the weight of their gaze upon me. But I'm not afraid. I'm just doing my job, maintaining the balance of nature.

As the sun begins to set, casting long shadows across the forest floor, I feel a sense of satisfaction. The world is safe, for now. The humans will leave, and the forest will heal. It's a fragile existence, but it's the only one I know.

I'll continue to weave my web of shadows, to maintain the delicate balance of the ecosystem. It's a never-ending task, one that requires great sacrifice. But I'm willing to make that sacrifice, for the sake of the forest, and for the sake of the world.

As I disappear into the trees, the wind whispers a final secret in my ear. "You're not alone, Emilia. There are others like you, watching and waiting." I smile, a sense of solidarity washing over me. We're the guardians of the forest, the keepers of its secrets. And we'll continue to do our job, no matter the cost.

prompt: An alien invasion happens during an alien invasion .
story: It ’ s funny how naïve science fiction writers were . They assumed we would be on the same level as aliens – that our battles would be fought on even ground . They egotistically thought that humans might even have an edge for our “ special ” upbringing on Earth . <newline> <newline> But space is big . Really big . By the time , we finally found a way to quickly traverse it , we figured out the truth . Space isn ’ t the biggest boundary separating alien civilizations . <newline> <newline> The universe formed 14 billion years ago , and it ’ s been habitable for much of that time . In comparison , our ape ancestors “ only ” appeared a few tens of millions of years ago , and we ’ ve only been able to reach out into the void for about a hundred years now . <newline> <newline> Time is the boundary that truly separates life . It ’ s likely that in the whole Milky Way , there is no alien race that is exactly on our technology level . There are perhaps millions of races that are eons behind us , and many more that are just as far ahead . Some aliens are but ants to us . If we desired , we could crush them without a second thought . Other aliens , however , are gods . Their technological capability is beyond our understanding , beyond anything we could ever dream . <newline> <newline> With such technological disparity , it seems almost inevitable that the universe is one giant game of predator and prey . As a young species just entering the galactic community , we are prey to all and predator to none . Some men dream of finding worlds that we can colonize , worlds where we can be the predators , but they don ’ t realize that we ’ re millions , even billions of years behind . <newline> <newline> Until recently , we believed that maybe we ’ re late bloomers , billions of years late – that maybe we don ’ t have a place in this universe . If the universe is cold and unforgiving , the old and strong swallowing up the younger , weaker species , what chance did we have ? With such powerful alien civilizations already in power around the galaxy , how could we even make it a hundred years without being crushed by a superior force ? <newline> <newline> Four days ago , an alien species of unknown origin entered the solar system . Their ships were incomprehensibly fast , and their strange weaponry tore through our defenses with little to no resistance . In a matter of minutes , the human defense was shattered . We were broken and vulnerable . The Earth and her colonies were ripe for the taking , a useful colony world to these dominant aliens . <newline> <newline> They descended upon our colonies , rounding us up in billions . They vaporized our structures and facilities and built their own . At this moment , we knew there was nothing special about us . We were a small , insignificant species whose fate was at the mercy of this superior race . <newline> <newline> But then they arrived . We called them the Arbiters , even though we never saw one in person . They sent one ship , the size of a small car . At this sight , the invaders scattered and ran , abandoning their projects and leaving our solar system . But they were too slow for the Arbiter ship – in an instant , it unleashed whatever arcane forces it had at its command , and the invaders completely disappeared . Our planets somehow reverted to their pre-invasion state , and indeed the only remaining evidence of the invasion was in our memories . <newline> <newline> It was at that moment that we understood . This was how the prey survived . This was how civilizations were allowed to form . <newline> <newline> It was at that moment that we made the choice . We abandoned our dreams of conquest and victory . We wouldn ’ t become invaders . We would become Arbiters . <newline>

prompt: An alien invasion happens during an alien invasion .
story:
The sky was a deep, foreboding crimson, like the belly of a beast that had swallowed the sun whole. The air was heavy with the acrid scent of ozone and smoke, a noxious miasma that clung to every surface like a bad omen. It was as if the very fabric of reality had been torn asunder, revealing a glimpse of the abyss that lurked beyond the veil of sanity.

Dr. Elara Vex crouched behind a crumbling concrete wall, her eyes fixed on the chaos unfolding before her. The streets were a sea of panicked faces, screaming and running in every direction. The once-familiar buildings now stood as twisted, nightmarish silhouettes, their windows shattered like the fragile dreams of the city's inhabitants.

And then, the ships came.

Gigantic, saucer-shaped vessels descended from the sky, their hulls a latticework of pulsing, bioluminescent tendrils that seemed to writhe and twist like living serpents. The air was filled with the deafening roar of their engines, a cacophony that threatened to shatter the eardrums of anyone who dared to listen.

Elara's gaze was drawn to the lead ship, its hull a deep, burnished silver that seemed to absorb the light around it. The alien creatures that emerged from its belly were unlike anything she had ever seen. They were tall, with skin that shifted and flowed like the surface of a liquid, and eyes that burned with an otherworldly green fire.

As the creatures began to move through the city, Elara felt a sense of detachment wash over her. It was as if she was watching a scene from a distant, fading memory, one that she couldn't quite grasp or understand. The creatures moved with a purpose, their long, spindly limbs carrying them with an unnatural ease through the rubble-strewn streets.

One of them, a towering monstrosity with eyes that burned like hot coals, caught Elara's gaze. For a moment, they locked eyes, and Elara felt a jolt of recognition, as if she had stumbled upon a long-lost piece of herself. The creature's gaze was a mirror, reflecting back at her the deepest, darkest fears that she had long suppressed.

And then, it was gone, lost in the sea of chaos that surrounded her. Elara was left standing alone, her heart pounding in her chest like a drum. She knew that she had to get out of there, to escape the city before it was too late. But as she turned to flee, she felt a hand on her shoulder, a cold, clammy grip that seemed to hold her in place.

The creature's eyes were back, burning with an intensity that made Elara's skin crawl. She knew that she was trapped, that she was at the mercy of these alien invaders. And in that moment, she felt a sense of despair wash over her, a sense of hopelessness that seemed to suffocate her.

The world was ending, and Elara was powerless to stop it.

prompt: Season 30 of Game of Thrones
story:
The air reeked of smoke and desperation as the Seven Kingdoms teetered on the precipice of chaos. In the midst of this maelstrom, a lone figure emerged from the shadows of King's Landing's narrow alleys. Kael, a former member of the Kingsguard, navigated the treacherous streets with a quiet confidence that belied the turmoil brewing within him.

As he walked, the flickering torches cast eerie silhouettes on the walls, like skeletal fingers grasping for the living. The city's inhabitants huddled in doorways, their eyes sunken and their faces etched with fear. The Great War had left its mark, and the people of King's Landing were beginning to realize that the true enemy was not the Night King, but the darkness that lurked within their own hearts.

Kael's thoughts were consumed by the weight of his own guilt. He had once sworn to protect the realm, to uphold the honor of the Kingsguard. But as the years passed, he watched as the institution he had sworn to defend crumbled beneath the weight of corruption and deceit. The once-noble knights had become nothing more than pawns in the game of thrones, their loyalty bought and sold like commodities on the black market.

As he turned a corner, Kael caught sight of a figure waiting for him in the shadows. It was a young woman, her eyes blazing with a fierce determination that seemed to pierce the very soul. She was a member of the rebellion, a group of rebels determined to bring down the Iron Throne and forge a new path for the Seven Kingdoms.

"Kael," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "I've been searching for you. We need your help."

Kael's instincts screamed at him to flee, to leave the rebellion to its fate. But something about the woman's words resonated deep within him. Perhaps it was the echo of his own lost honor, or the promise of a chance to make amends for past mistakes. Whatever the reason, Kael found himself nodding, his hand reaching out to grasp the woman's.

Together, they navigated the treacherous landscape of King's Landing, avoiding the watchful eyes of the Lannisters and the treacherous whispers of the Small Council. They moved with a quiet purpose, their footsteps echoing off the stone walls as they made their way towards the city's ancient heart.

There, in the great hall of the Red Keep, they found a gathering of rebels, their faces set with determination and their eyes burning with a fierce resolve. The woman, whose name was Aria, stood before them, her voice ringing out across the hall.

"We will not be silenced," she declared. "We will not be defeated. We will rise up, and we will take back our kingdom."

As the rebels cheered, Kael felt a spark of hope ignite within him. Perhaps, just perhaps, there was a way to redeem the honor he had lost, to forge a new path for the Seven Kingdoms. And as the flames of rebellion burned bright, he knew that he would stand alongside Aria, and together, they would bring down the darkness that had consumed King's Landing.

prompt: The worst job interview anyone has ever had
story: *Is that fucking mustard ? * <newline> <newline> Jack stared at his reflection in the public bathroom mirror . To the left of his emerald green tie was a muddy yellow stain . He replayed this morning 's events in his head , the moment he picked *that* shirt over the other , completely oblivious to the stain . He could n't remember ever eating in that shirt , and yet somehow , the stain was there . This was the most important interview of Jack 's underwhelming life , and now he had to face it with a little yellow spot of disgrace . <newline> <newline> He returned to the lobby , trying to decide whether he should try to hide the spot with his tie . Before he could decide , however , the secretary called his name , and beckoned him towards the massive wooden doors behind her desk . <newline> <newline> Jack slowly pushed the door open , poking his head in like some sort of child entering the principal 's office . A man sat at a large , expensive looking desk , the sun rising through the windows behind him . He was scribbling something in a leather bound book . <newline> <newline> `` Are you going to come in , or just stare at me from over there ? '' He asked . <newline> <newline> *Well , that 's a great start . * <newline> <newline> Jack approached the desk , holding his hand over the stain on his shirt . An oversized leather chair sat opposite the interviewer , and Jack helped himself to it . He sat there , silent , holding his hand over his heart -- concealing the pesky stain . <newline> <newline> The man finished his scribbling , and leaned back in his chair , meeting Jack 's gaze . <newline> <newline> `` You 're Jack ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Yes , sir , '' he responded , his voice cracking . *What kind of forty year old man had a cracking voice ? This is doomed . * <newline> <newline> The man 's gaze fell to Jack 's hand . `` Are you planning on saying the pledge of allegiance ? '' <newline> <newline> Jack 's heart was racing . With a series of nervous twitches , he moved his hand away from his chest , and rested it in his lap . <newline> <newline> `` Oh . '' The man 's face was expressionless . `` I probably would n't have noticed it if you had n't done that . '' <newline> <newline> That led Jack to let out the most awkward , loud , wet-sounding snort he 'd ever made in his life . It was like he had tried to chuckle with his head in a bowl of pudding ; and to make matters worse , it sent a bead of snot flying straight at a picture of the interviewer 's wife . <newline> <newline> *Why the hell was that picture even facing away from him ? * <newline> <newline> Both men were dumbstruck . The interviewer sat silent , staring at his wife 's mucous-covered face . <newline> <newline> `` I ... I 'm so sorry , '' Jack said in a rush . He stood quickly , and leaned forward to wipe the picture with his sleeve . <newline> <newline> `` Do n't -- '' the man began , as Jack instead knocked the picture over , and into a small bottle of ink . The ink darted across the desk , and splashed directly on the interviewer 's lap . <newline> <newline> `` I 'm sorry ! Oh , god , I 'm sorry ! '' Jack was nearly in tears , as he ran around the desk to try to help . He pulled a handkerchief from his jacket , and began patting the desk , and the interviewer . He looked up when he realized what an odd situation he had found himself in , and found the man staring at him with disgust . <newline> <newline> *Shit , I 've done it now . * <newline> <newline> He jumped up quickly with the intention of just returning to his seat . Without realizing it , he used the man 's legs as leverage , which pushed the rolling chair -- with the interviewer in it -- backwards and into the window . The glass cracked , and the man had an expression of both fear and rage . <newline> <newline> Jack threw his hands up . `` I 'm so sorry ! This is unbelievable , I just -- '' <newline> <newline> `` Get out . '' He lifted a single finger and pointed towards the doors . <newline> <newline> Jack hung his head low , and quietly exited the office . <newline> <newline> He walked down several flights of stairs and sat in his car before he realized he had left his wallet behind .

prompt: The worst job interview anyone has ever had
story:
The fluorescent lights overhead seemed to hum in sync with the cacophony of dread that had taken up residence in Emily's stomach. She fidgeted with the hem of her dress, the fabric a dull, institutional grey that matched the mood of the drab office she found herself in. The receptionist, a woman with a face that seemed chiseled from granite, looked up from her phone and raised an eyebrow.

"Emily Wilson, you're here for the marketing position," she stated, her voice as flat as the coffee table in the waiting room.

Emily nodded, her eyes darting around the room as if searching for an escape route. The walls were adorned with bland, corporate artwork – a series of watercolors depicting serene landscapes, each one more soulless than the last. A potted plant on the receptionist's desk seemed to be the only living thing in the room, its leaves wilting in the dry air.

As Emily waited, she couldn't help but think about the countless job interviews she'd endured, each one a grueling exercise in self-presentation. She'd practiced her responses to every possible question, honed her smile, and perfected her "can-do" attitude. But this one felt different. This one felt like a trap, a cleverly designed puzzle with no clear solution.

The interviewer, a man with a face that seemed to be carved from the same granite as the receptionist, emerged from the doorway. He was a tall, imposing figure, his eyes narrowed behind a pair of wire-rimmed glasses.

"Ah, Emily Wilson," he said, his voice dripping with a condescending warmth. "Welcome to our humble abode of corporate drudgery."

Emily forced a smile, her mind racing with worst-case scenarios. She launched into her carefully rehearsed speech, but the words felt hollow, like she was reciting a script written by someone else. The interviewer listened intently, his expression a mask of polite interest.

As the interview drew to a close, Emily felt a sense of desperation creeping in. She was running out of time, and she knew she was running out of chances. The interviewer leaned forward, his eyes glinting with a sinister light.

"So, Emily," he said, his voice low and menacing. "Tell me, what makes you think you're qualified for this position?"

Emily hesitated, her mind racing with the countless hours she'd spent preparing for this moment. But as she looked into the interviewer's eyes, she saw something that made her heart sink. She saw a man who didn't care about her qualifications, who didn't care about her passion or her drive. He saw a commodity, a product to be packaged and sold.

In that moment, Emily knew she was done. She stood up, her chair scraping against the floor, and walked out of the office without a word. As she emerged into the bright sunlight, she felt a sense of liberation wash over her. She knew she'd never set foot in that office again, and she knew she'd never be a part of that soulless, corporate machine.

The receptionist's voice called out after her, a voice that seemed to come from a million miles away. "Emily Wilson, you're fired."

Emily smiled, a small, triumphant smile. She knew she'd made the right decision, even if it meant walking away from a job that would have suffocated her soul.

story: He was going to the stars ! Finally ! He had always dreamed of going to the stars and today they were finally letting him . And he had won the lottery for he and his family were picked with many others to go forth and multiply , colonizing the galaxy . <newline> <newline> After all he was destined for this , destined to be an astronaut to walk among the stars . Did he not wear a star around his neck everyday ? He smiled , thinking to himself , 'gosh what a lucky boy I am . I 'll bet all the other kids at school will be so jealous of me when I tell them where I went ... And maybe they wo n't pick on me for my star necklace anymore ... ' <newline> <newline> And so they went , two by two , following the orders of the stern man in the nice uniform . <newline> `` Please remove all your clothing and any loose articles . '' <newline> `` Place them in the cubicles provided '' <newline> `` Please step into the detoxification chamber where you will be cleansed . 'Maybe I should take a nice nap ' he thought as he curled up on the floor , his hand still grasping his necklace tightly . <newline> <newline> The stern man with the nice uniform strode into the room wearing a gas mask . <newline> <newline> `` Batch 17 complete . '' <newline>

prompt: A boy pretends he is an astronaut in order to help cope with concepts and situations he ca n't understand .
story:
The stars twinkled like a million scattered diamonds on the ceiling, and 10-year-old Jax's imagination soared. He was no longer a boy in a small bedroom, but an astronaut on a mission to Mars. His spacesuit, a makeshift affair cobbled together from a cardboard box and some torn fabric, felt like the real deal. The helmet, a tin can with a makeshift visor, made him feel invincible.

Jax's mom had been struggling to explain the concept of climate change to him. The numbers and percentages swirled in his head like a tornado, leaving him feeling lost and scared. But when he put on his astronaut suit, the world became a different place. The problems that had been plaguing him just hours before – the rising temperatures, the melting ice caps – became distant, abstract threats to a planet he was sworn to protect.

As he floated through the "galaxy" of his bedroom, Jax's mind began to wander. He imagined the Martian landscape, a barren expanse of red sand and rock. He pictured the towering mountains, the deep valleys, and the vast oceans that covered most of the planet. The more he explored, the more he realized that Mars was just like Earth – fragile, beautiful, and in need of protection.

But Jax's thoughts were interrupted by the sound of his mom's voice, calling him downstairs for dinner. He reluctantly removed his helmet, feeling a pang of disappointment. The world outside his bedroom window was still the same – the same messy streets, the same crowded houses, the same worried faces.

As he sat down to eat, Jax's mom asked him about his day. He hesitated, unsure of how to explain the fantastical world he had created. But then, something shifted inside him. He began to talk about his astronaut suit, about the stars and the planets, about the vastness of space. His mom listened, her eyes filled with a mix of wonder and concern.

For the first time, Jax felt like he was being heard. His mom wasn't just a person who was trying to explain complicated things to him; she was a fellow traveler in the vast expanse of the universe. Together, they could explore the unknown, face the challenges that lay ahead, and find a way to make the world a better place.

As they finished dinner and began to clear the table, Jax's mom reached out and took his hand. "You know, Jax," she said, "you're not just an astronaut. You're a part of this world, and this world is a part of you. We're all in this together."

Jax looked up at her, feeling a sense of peace wash over him. He knew that he still had a lot to learn, but with his mom by his side, he felt like he could face anything. The stars twinkled on, a reminder of the infinite possibilities that lay ahead. And Jax, still wearing his astronaut suit, felt like he was ready to take on the universe.

prompt: The Earth is flat , you , as the head of NASA , have to explain to the incoming President why its a secret .
story: The early greek philosophers investigated and implied it , and early explorers found answers when they continued to sail without falling off at ends . However , what these early individuals did not know was that their very initial assumption of planet earth being flat was correct . What you see is what you get . Sailing on forever did not mean that the ocean was all connected through gravity and a round surface . This occurred only because specialized ocean currents forced travelers to turn in a never ending circle around the circumference of the flat planet . These currents did not consist of North , West , East , or South . They come from none of these but also a combination of them . They are furthermore an aspect of earth that has not been fully studied or discovered . As more and more individuals of our planet concluded that the earth was round after some time , scientists and geographers concurred that this was correct without any expansion of knowledge or research . I , however , discovered the real answer to our earth 's shape some time ago . I was planning a space trip for my team at NASA , when I decided that for once I wanted to go for a test launch before my team was sent up . Traveling to space by oneself is typically very discouraged by the scientists at NASA or any other physicist you might ask . I , being an overly confident astrologer and astronaut , refused to ever listen to the opinions of other space lovers regarding rocket launch risks . This is mostly because my planned space launches never went wrong . My team and I have always been able to succeed and bring back valuable information from the strange world above . As long as my rocket robots were able to perform the functions my team was typically asked to do , I would achieve a victorious mission . When I ventured into orbit , I gazed outside the cold and still window of the shuttle for quite sometime . I began tracing drawing after drawing of what the earth was revealing to me . Years and years went by and I eventually could not believe my own eyes . I realized the world I was staring at never continued after each identifiable horizon . It was flat . Our very home of earth was flatter than a pancake , frisbee , Cameron Diaz 's chest , or a sheet of paper . Every hypothesis of our earth being round was a giant mistake . I realized about two days after my discovery that I was probably the only human being inhabiting the planet that was aware of this . When I returned back home from my mission , I canceled the trip my team was meant to take about nine months after mine . I came up with multiple diagrams and charts in order to help me decide whether I should let the discovery be known and open to the public , or not . After deep consideration and thought , I decided that it would be a disaster if I ever let the finding be known . I canceled all future NASA operations after that . It was just too dangerous to let anymore NASA team members become vulnerable to discovering the same concept I had . There were many reasons for my desire to keep the discovery a secret . For one , many people would be outraged and blame the people in power 's actual stupidity for instead lying to everyone about something that they should have known about right away . Combat would most likely occur between territories blaming each other for something they both had nothing to do with . This is just my opinion but let 's be honest , pretty much every person on our planet believes they are entitled to know everything . Also , all transportation devices would be altered in compliance to the more realistic routes that could be taken around the globe . Less revenue would be generated because of this and less revenue is the last thing our country can afford to lose at a time of economic crisis . And more importantly , I would probably be brutally murdered for keeping such a secret to myself for so long . And who am I to have made myself the person to identify such a big trait of our solar system , right ? Anyway Mr. Trump , I hope you understand my plead to have this information remain confidential . It is of the utmost importance to me and I hope to you as well . I can only wish that you ignore the urge to use this discovery as a personal profit for yourself . If you do decide to proceed with this , I just ask that you leave my name and information completely out of the picture . I also thoroughly hope that you understood the majority of this explanation and request . If by chance you did not , I can restate myself in more simpler of terms . Oh ! and one other thing . I happened to discover that space matter is actually another form of H2O and NaCl , but modified for the specific needs of our varying planets in our solar system . Think of it this way , each planet acts as a continent that is fixed upon a body of `` space '' instead of ocean water . While our Earth has Saturn , Neptune , and Uranus , our North America has South American , Europe , and Asia . This discovery however is for another day and needs further investigation . The answers to this upcoming examination shall be shared with you as well , as long as you agree to keep my initial request sacred . Thank you for your time .

prompt: The Earth is flat , you , as the head of NASA , have to explain to the incoming President why its a secret .
story:
I stood before the Oval Office, my eyes fixed on the imposing figure of the incoming President, their gaze piercing as they awaited my explanation. The weight of the world rested on my shoulders, and I knew that the fate of humanity's understanding of our planet hung precariously in the balance.

"Mr. President," I began, my voice steady, "I'm sure you're aware of the...unconventional theories surrounding the Earth's shape."

The President's expression remained inscrutable, their eyes narrowing ever so slightly as they leaned forward in their chair. "I've heard whispers, of course. But I'm not sure I understand what you're getting at."

I took a deep breath, choosing my words carefully. "The Earth is not, in fact, a sphere. It's flat."

The room fell silent, the only sound the soft hum of the air conditioning unit. The President's eyes locked onto mine, a spark of curiosity igniting within them.

"I know this may come as a shock," I continued, "but the evidence is overwhelming. The horizon always appears to be at eye level, the lack of visible curvature when viewed from a distance, the fact that the Earth's shadow on the moon during a lunar eclipse is always round, not elliptical...these are just a few of the many indicators that suggest our planet is, in fact, flat."

The President's expression remained unreadable, but I could sense a flicker of skepticism behind their eyes. I pressed on, knowing that I had to convince them of the truth.

"But it's not just about the science, Mr. President," I said, my voice taking on a more personal tone. "The flat Earth theory has been a part of human culture for centuries, with many people believing it to be a fundamental aspect of their faith or worldview. To dismiss it outright would be to ignore the experiences and perspectives of millions of people around the world."

The President's gaze never wavered, but I could see the wheels turning in their mind. They were considering the implications of my words, weighing the potential consequences of revealing a secret that had been hidden for so long.

Finally, after what felt like an eternity, they spoke. "I see," they said, their voice measured. "And what do you propose we do with this information, Dr. Patel?"

I took a deep breath, knowing that I had to tread carefully. "I recommend that we establish a task force to investigate the flat Earth theory, to gather more evidence and understand the underlying motivations behind it. We must also consider the potential impact on global politics and international relations, as well as the emotional and psychological toll that this revelation may take on individuals and communities around the world."

The President nodded thoughtfully, their eyes never leaving mine. "I agree," they said finally. "But I must warn you, Dr. Patel, this is a secret that must be kept at all costs. We cannot afford to have this information leak to the public, not yet, at least."

I nodded in agreement, knowing that I had just been entrusted with a weighty responsibility. As I left the Oval Office, I couldn't help but wonder what the future held for humanity, and whether we would ever be able to reconcile our understanding of the world with the truth that lay before us.
