prompt: Satan faces the issues of being a single parent to the babies and children sacrificed to him
story:
In the dimly lit, crimson-hued caverns of the underworld, a lone figure sat amidst the scattered remnants of a thousand midnights. The air reeked of brimstone and regret as Satan, the fallen king, cradled a small, porcelain doll in his massive, clawed hands. The doll's face was a haunting replica of a child he had once known, a tiny, winged thing that had been torn from its mother's arms in a fit of rage.

Satan's eyes, once blazing with an infernal fire, now seemed dull and tired, weighed down by the crushing burden of his responsibilities. He was a single parent, forced to care for the countless orphans he had fathered in the depths of the underworld. The babies and children, each one a tiny, screaming reminder of his own failures and the weight of his eternal damnation.

As he rocked the doll back and forth, a faint, mournful melody drifted through the caverns, a haunting lullaby that seemed to echo the whispers of the damned. Satan's thoughts turned to the countless others, the tiny, helpless souls who had been torn from their mothers' arms and left to his care. He thought of the ones who had been born with horns, their eyes glowing with an otherworldly light, and the ones who had been born with wings, their tiny hearts beating with a fierce, angelic spirit.

He thought of the ones who had been born with no eyes at all, their bodies twisted and deformed, their screams echoing through the caverns as they struggled to breathe. And he thought of the ones who had been born with eyes that burned with an inner fire, their tiny hands grasping for the light, even as the darkness closed in around them.

Satan's heart, long thought to be a cold, black stone, ached with a deep, abiding sorrow. He was a father, a guardian, a protector, and yet he was powerless to save them all. The weight of his responsibilities was crushing, the burden of his guilt suffocating.

As the melody faded away, Satan's thoughts turned to the one being who had ever shown him kindness, a young woman named Lilith, who had been his first love, his first companion, and his first mother. She had been the one who had given him the gift of fatherhood, who had shown him the beauty of parenthood, and who had been taken from him in a fit of rage.

Satan's eyes welled up with tears as he remembered the day she had left him, the day she had walked away from the underworld, leaving him to care for the countless orphans alone. He remembered the sound of her laughter, the feel of her touch, and the taste of her tears.

As the memories washed over him, Satan's grip on the doll tightened, his fingers digging deep into the porcelain as if he could hold on to the past, to the love they had shared, and to the hope that one day, he might find a way to make things right. But for now, he was left alone, a single parent to a thousand midnights, his heart heavy with the weight of his responsibilities, and his soul tormented by the ghosts of his own making.

prompt: After Earth is destroyed , the surviving humans colonize two different planets . All contact between the two groups was lost , until they rediscover each other thousands of years later .
story: Tartok looked up . There was a falling star , an angel that had displeased Mother Sky . Tartok looked back at the water his narrow canoe was on , murky in the nighttime . He had better get back soon , or he could freeze to death . Water had splashed into his small raft and splattered him with currents of ice . He rowed back to shore , where his son Alrak , almost taller than his mother , who was much taller than Tartok , was waiting . He had the hounds tied up , ready to get loose and bring the man and his son back to their home . <newline> <newline> `` Alrak , '' Tartok said . `` Did you feed them ? '' <newline> <newline> `` No , '' Alrak said , short and sweet , the way his strict father demanded . <newline> <newline> `` Give them one fish to split between them . When we get home they will have one half buffalo steak each . These dogs worked hard today , bringing us all the way out here . '' <newline> <newline> `` Yes sir , '' Alrak said , quickly picking up a small fish and plopping it in front of the dogs . They bit into it ravenously , having not been fed all day . The rest of the fish would feed Tartok , his wife , his two sons , and his three daughters all week . While he and Alrak , the second-born of all seven children , were out hunting , his daughters were at home learning to cook , clean , and comfort by their mother , who was a master of all three . The youngest of the seven , Tartok 's second son was probably asleep . He would be taught to hunt tomorrow by his father and his brother . They had a plentiful fish harvest this week and would not need to come back . Sometimes these trips only sufficed enough food to feed them for half a week , or a day , or sometimes not even that . On the ice caps of Malwrak , the only parts inhabitable , anything could happen . <newline> <newline> As the dogs pulled the heavy sled connected to the canoe ahead and home , Tartok looked up . The falling star was back , but brighter than before . It left a red streak across the sky , and appeared to be headed to the center of the capital of Malwrak , which was much more advanced than here at the very edges of civilization . Tartok wondered what , if anything would happen if the star crashed . <newline> _________________ <newline> Talia mashed at buttons on the console . `` No , no , no ! '' she screamed . The ship could n't crash , not after how far they had come . They had sailed around the sun just to get here , the place people though might , might hold life . Talia , along with Jarak and Syphon had been sent on the ship after years of training . No one knew what the planet would be like ; large or small , hot or cold , high gravity or low gravity . They had trained for every possibility , and had gone through countless simulations of landing , which had to be done manually despite autopilot , but no one thought they could just run out of fuel ! Someone must have emptied some . <newline> <newline> `` Ship diagnostic ! '' she yelled . A sleek feminine voice calmly said , `` Oxygen : 100 % . Crew : 100 % . Weapons : 100 % . Shiel -- '' <newline> <newline> `` Just tell me what 's wrong ! '' Talia screamed . <newline> <newline> The ship paused for a moment before saying , `` Autopilot scrambled . Prepare for landing . '' <newline> <newline> `` No ! There 's nowhere to land ! '' she said , but the ship did not respond . <newline> A door opened behind her and Jarak walked in . <newline> <newline> `` Talia ! '' he said . `` Why are we landing ? There 's only cities beneath us -- '' <newline> <newline> `` *The autopilot is n't working ! * '' she yelled . `` Help me fly this thing ! '' <newline> <newline> Jarak ran forward and sat in the copilot seat . He had been the top of the landing class . He would know what to do . <newline> <newline> He looked out from the screen , showing what was outside the front of the ship despite the cockpit being in the very back . <newline> <newline> `` Um , there 's a field over there , '' he said . He started to steer the ship in the direction he had pointed , away from the towering buildings which seemed to be made of iridescent ice . The ship swerved , knocking into one of the buildings . A crater formed and some ice fell to the street below , but the sleek ship continued on its course . The place they were heading for was about 50 miles away , near the frigid sea that contained the borders of this country . The ship had detected the only life besides plants were at the pole . The city in the middle of the pole certainly proved that . <newline> <newline> They moved quickly towards the icy plain . There was a small cabin below , about two hundred meters from the sharp drop off of a cliff . Suddenly Jarak yelled . <newline> <newline> `` What ? '' Talia asked , panicked . <newline> <newline> `` Ca n't you see ? We 're overshooting the ice ! We 're going to land in the ocean ! '' <newline> <newline> Talia quickly tried to serve the ship , but at the angle they were travelling they had two possible destinations : the ocean , straight ahead , or the wall of a cliff made of ice if they turned . <newline> Talia and Jarak prepped for a water landing . <newline> ________________________ <newline> `` Did you see the falling star ? '' asked Tartok 's wife , Jæra when they had finished their dinner of fish steaks . <newline> <newline> `` Yes , as we were coming home , '' Tartok said bitterly . Alrak had given each dog a whole steak each , not half . They had wasted many steaks and would not be able to eat as plentiful this week , just the fish he had harvested . <newline> <newline> `` Were you hurt ? '' Jæra asked . <newline> <newline> `` No , we are fine . '' Tartok said . Jæra was always worrying . She worried too much , Tartok thought . <newline> <newline> Suddenly they heard a roaring above them , like a bird but sharper , stronger , somehow ... wrong . <newline> <newline> `` What was that ? '' Jæra asked . <newline> <newline> `` I do not know , '' Tartok said . He got up from his chair , one of two in the house , the other occupied by Jæra , and walked to the door . As he pushed it open , a sight unfolded that he could never have imagined . <newline> <newline> A metal bird with fire feet was flying towards the water . It would crash , but there was no other way for it to land without crashing into the cliff and possibly making the cliff fall into the water . Jæra had never wanted to be so close to the water , but Tartok had always said that they were far enough . She may have been right . <newline> <newline> The metal bird was large , large enough to hold Tartok 's entire family and the sleddogs . Suddenly part of its side flew off , and people jumped out . They had packs on their back , and as soon as they were in the air they pulled on a string and fell slowly , down and to the side . Only three jumped out , and the ship continued on its path to the ocean . <newline> <newline> When one of the people landed , Tartok walked up to them . `` What is going on here ? '' he asked . <newline> <newline> The person replied in a language very similar to Tartok 's . They were different , but Tartok could understand snippets . <newline> <newline> `` World ... ship ... first ... talk ... help . '' <newline> <newline> `` What do you need help with ? '' he asked , ready to do whatever he could to help people . He may be small and bittersweet , but Tartok was always ready to help . <newline> ________________________________________ <newline> The man in front of Syphon was speaking in a primal language . Talia hoped that Syphon would be able to understand him . She was sent as a translator , having studied all the languages of their original home , what was called something like `` Terr '' or `` Ert , '' that were remembered . <newline> <newline> `` We were sent to this world , '' she said , `` in that ship . You are the first people of another planet we have ever talked to . Will you help us make peace ? '' she asked in the language they used on their home planet of Lœa . <newline> <newline> The man said something in the primal language , and Syphon told Talia , `` He 's willing to help , but he only partially understands us . Do you have the ICD ? '' Syphon asked . ICD stood for *Interplanetary Communication Device* . <newline> Talia stared at her , wordless . `` I ... I thought you had it , '' she said . <newline> <newline> Syphon 's face went a stark pallor , matching the blue-white ice . `` Jarak ! You have the ICD , right ? '' she asked . <newline> <newline> `` No , '' he said . `` Why ? Do n't one of <newline> you ... Oh shit , you guys forgot it , did n't you ? '' Jarak was not one to cuss unless the situation was dire , which this certainly was . If they could n't find it , they would n't be able to tell the Lœans what they had found ! They 'd be stuck in this icy wilderness for their entire lives ! <newline> <newline> `` Oh , shit shit shit , '' Jarak said . `` Um , it was in the cockpit , right ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Yeah , '' Talia said . `` How did I forget it ? '' she muttered . <newline> <newline> `` Okay , we need to go find it . Ask him if he has rope , '' Jarak said to Syphon . <newline> <newline> Syphon translated the message since the man did n't speak their own language . He replied in the same language , and Syphon said , `` He says he can understand me now and that he does have rope . He 's willing to help us . '' <newline> <newline> `` Tell him to go get the rope , and that we do n't need his help . We can scale the cliff and get it ourselves . '' Jarak said bitterly . <newline> <newline> As Syphon translated , Talia said , `` Why should n't we have his help ? He probably knows the cliff and water better than us , and if we 're going to establish stable connections to this planet we may as well start now . '' <newline> <newline> The man asked something and Syphon replied . He said something again , and Syphon said , `` He says he knows how to scale the cliff and how deep the water is at places . He wants to help . '' <newline> <newline> Jarak sighed . `` Fine , but tell him to hurry . '' <newline> ________________________________________ <newline> Tartok hurried to the shed where the dogs lived , just large enough for all of them and the ropes . He slammed open the door and some of the dogs looked up , bored . He grabbed the rope he used to tie them to the sled . It would be enough to scale the cliff , about fifteen meters ; not very tall unless the bottom is a tide pool of liquid ice with spiky rock at the bottom , poking up randomly . He took it and some of the bones from the dogs ' dinners . He crushed them into a crack in the ice where they held . He stepped on it , and it held him . He slammed another right behind it , trying the same test . If it held him , it would certainly hold the young , bitter man who had escaped the bird . The man was tall but thin , probably weighing a little more than Tartok himself . He tied the rope around the bones and told the translating woman , `` I am ready to go with the man . '' When she tells her crew , she replies , `` The man is not going . The other woman is . '' <newline> <newline> Tartok is shocked . Surely the man is the captain of the crew ? <newline> <newline> It does not matter much . These people are from some far odd land and need help . They have different customs . Tartok is not one to judge . <newline> <newline> `` Okay , '' he says as the translator relays his message . `` Let 's get to work . ''

prompt: After Earth is destroyed , the surviving humans colonize two different planets . All contact between the two groups was lost , until they rediscover each other thousands of years later .
story:
The sky was a deep, bruised purple, like a bruise that refused to heal. The air was heavy with the scent of ozone and smoke, a constant reminder of the devastation that had ravaged the earth. The once-blue oceans now lay dry and cracked, their beds of coral and seaweed bleached white as bone.

On one of the two planets, the survivors of the Great Upheaval had built a new home. They called it Nova Terra, a name that reflected their hope and determination. The city was a sprawling metropolis, its towers and spires reaching for the sky like giant's fists. The streets were narrow and winding, lined with strange, glowing plants that cast an ethereal light over the inhabitants.

But on the other planet, the survivors had built a different kind of city. They called it Aethereia, a name that reflected the otherworldly beauty of their surroundings. The city was a labyrinth of crystal and silver, its walls and towers reflecting the colors of the sky like a shard of glass. The streets were wide and straight, lined with strange, glowing trees that cast a soft, blue light over the inhabitants.

For thousands of years, the two cities had existed in isolation, their inhabitants living separate lives, unaware of the existence of the other. They had developed different cultures, different languages, and different customs. But despite their differences, they shared a common bond - a shared history, a shared memory of the world that had been lost.

And then, one day, something changed. A strange, glowing object appeared in the sky, its light piercing the darkness like a beacon. The inhabitants of Nova Terra and Aethereia looked up, their eyes fixed on the object as it descended, its light growing brighter and brighter until it was a blinding flash.

When the light faded, the inhabitants of both cities saw something that made their hearts skip a beat. A ship, its hull battered and scarred, had landed on the outskirts of their cities. And on the ship, standing on the deck, was a figure - a figure that looked uncannily like one of them.

The figure stumbled forward, its eyes fixed on the inhabitants of the two cities. It was a woman, her skin pale and her hair dark. She looked around, taking in the unfamiliar sights and sounds of the two cities. And then, she saw them - the inhabitants of Nova Terra and Aethereia, standing in the streets, their eyes fixed on her.

The woman's eyes widened in shock and wonder. She had seen the ruins of the old world, the remnants of a civilization that had been lost forever. But she had never seen anything like this - two cities, thriving and alive, despite the devastation that had ravaged the earth.

The inhabitants of Nova Terra and Aethereia stared back at her, their faces filled with a mix of emotions - fear, wonder, and curiosity. They had never seen anyone like her before, someone who seemed to be from another world.

The woman took a step forward, her eyes fixed on the inhabitants of the two cities. And then, she spoke - a voice that was barely above a whisper, but that carried across the distance like a prayer.

"I am from the old world," she said. "I am from the earth that was lost. And I have come to find out if you are the descendants of the people who lived here."

The inhabitants of Nova Terra and Aethereia looked at each other, their faces filled with a mix of emotions. And then, they nodded - a nod of recognition, a nod of understanding.

The woman smiled, her eyes shining with tears. And then, she reached out, her hand extended in a gesture of peace.

"We are the descendants," she said. "We are the people who lived here. And we have been waiting for you."

prompt: Every authority is baffled but for the past few years everyone has been receiving a Christmas present . To some delight and others horror , the gifts are based on how 'good ' you 've been .
story: Despite parents having said it for generations , * '' What did Santa get you ? `` * took on a whole new meaning on Christmas day , 2015 . <newline> <newline> On a day when the TVs around the country were usually playing Christmas songs from the 70 's , they were now fixed on the news channels , all with `` BREAKING NEWS '' banners flashing across the screen . Reports of robberies , with no sign of forced entry and cries over invasion of privacy , yet with no-one quite sure what it was of their privacy that was invaded . The only thing that was crystal clear was that during the night of Christmas eve , someone had entered each person 's home and placed presents under the tree . Not just randomly either . Each present was labeled and each mother , father and child in the home was accounted for . <newline> <newline> It took a while for some to notice , usually the families where the parents teased their children by delaying the gifts promising excitement and joy , but by midday everyone had discovered one extra present per person . Most children received expensive toys or video games and adults sometimes even found a new car parked outside ; keys in the ignition and a green tree hanging from the rear view mirror . <newline> <newline> Not everyone was happy though . Some had woken up on Christmas day to find something entirely different and unpleasant . Liars searched for their present only to find rotten fish , wrapped and pushed under floorboards . Men and women who had cheated on their spouses unwrapped their gifts to find naked action figures ; seemingly innocent enough but when picked up they would begin to reel off intimate details of their affairs while their partner was in the room . Needless to say , it was these very people who were shouting the loudest and writing to their local papers the quickest . <newline> <newline> The government was quick to step in , with the prime minister appearing outside his home in the late afternoon to speak to the nation . He spoke with countless microphones extended towards his face , but managed to keep his eyes on the camera placed dead center . <newline> <newline> * '' Good evening everyone . There does n't seem to be a single family across the nation who has n't been visited by 'Santa ' '' * he began , raising and bending two fingers to emphasize the fictional character . * '' I assure everyone that the government and I are doing our utmost to figure out what is going on , and to determine who is behind all of this . We ask for your patience as we begin our investigation . Please try to enjoy the rest of your Christmas ! `` * Without further comment , the PM waved as he retreated back into his home , where his staff awaited him . <newline> <newline> * '' God dammit , Linda . Find out what is going on ! `` * , the PM demanded as he threw off the reindeer knit his staff insisted he wear . <newline> <newline> Linda replied promptly , following the PM through to his office . * '' Of course , Sir . We have local law enforcement around the country inspecting people 's homes . I 'm not sure what we 're expecting to find though . Could it really be him ? * '' <newline> <newline> The head of the country stopped in his tracks , spun on his heels and stared straight into his assistant 's eyes for several moments without saying a word . Just as she was about to apologize , he stepped towards her , forcing her to step backwards towards the door . <newline> <newline> * '' Listen . I do n't care WHO did it . I do n't care WHY they did it . All I WANT is for the responsible party to be found and for their trespassin ' asses to be nailed to the wall . Am I clear ? `` * <newline> <newline> Linda , who was now half way out into the corridor , apologized profusely and span on her own heels and walked straight into the staff office . The PM adjusted the collar around his neck as he watched her scuttle away , then stormed back into his own office , locking the door behind him . <newline> <newline> He paced up and down the room , the heels of his shoes clicking off the hardwood flooring . He spent some time texting old friends in the police force , asking if they had any leads . When they did n't reply at a moment 's notice he threw his phone against the sofa at the back of the room . He eventually got tired of walking and returned to his desk where he had spent the whole morning before his staff demanded he speak to the press . <newline> <newline> Opening the drawer he pulled out a small box , wrapped in what seemed to be white wrapping paper with thin black lines . Upon closer inspection those lines were actually text from emails which the PM had written . Emails which should n't have seen the light of day . He held the box in his hands for several minutes , not reading what it had been wrapped in as he already knew it was all the information that would end his career . A career built upon bribes , deceit and some things much worse . With a heavy sigh he pushed his thumbs against the lid of the box and let it fall to the floor . <newline> <newline> The inside of the box was also lined with printed emails but in the center sat the hairband which he gave to his daughter the Christmas before he was elected . The daughter who was supposed to be on holiday , but who was now not answering her phone or emails . <newline> <newline> The PM sat at his desk with no holiday cheer around him , knowing that he had received , to put it lightly , the worst Christmas present in the country . Strangely it was n't the present or even his missing child that was haunting him the most . <newline> <newline> It was knowing that he had deserved it . <newline> <newline> -- -- -- - <newline> <newline> First writing prompt attempt ! Enjoy ! <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline>

prompt: Every authority is baffled but for the past few years everyone has been receiving a Christmas present . To some delight and others horror , the gifts are based on how 'good ' you 've been .
story:
The snowflakes danced in the air like a thousand tiny ballerinas, their delicate steps weaving a mesmerizing pattern as they settled on the pavement. It was Christmas morning, and the world was abuzz with the usual chaos of children's laughter and the distant rumble of carolers. But amidst the festive cheer, a sense of unease hung in the air like a thin veil of uncertainty.

For as long as anyone could remember, every citizen of the world had been receiving a Christmas present. Not just any present, but a gift tailored to their very soul. It was a phenomenon that had left authorities baffled, with some hailing it as a miracle and others decrying it as a harbinger of doom.

The first year it had started, people had been overjoyed. A young couple had received a beautiful, handcrafted music box that played a lullaby of their first date. A retired man had been given a vintage typewriter, which he had used to write a bestselling novel. The gift had been a surprise, but it had also been a validation of their hard work and dedication.

But as the years went by, the gifts had become increasingly...unsettling. A teenager had received a smartphone with a single, cryptic message: "You will never be happy." A businessman had been given a briefcase filled with nothing but worthless receipts and cancelled checks. A single mother had been presented with a bouquet of wilted flowers, accompanied by a note that read: "You are not enough."

The gifts had become a reflection of the world's collective guilt and shame. They were a reminder that our actions, no matter how small, had consequences. And the recipients, once filled with hope and excitement, were now left to grapple with the weight of their own moral failings.

As I walked through the crowded streets, I couldn't help but feel a sense of dread. What would I receive this year? Would it be a gift that would bring me joy, or one that would crush my spirits? I thought back to the previous year, when I had received a beautiful, leather-bound book. It was a gift that had been tailored to my love of literature, and it had brought me hours of comfort and solace.

But as I turned the pages, I had discovered a hidden message, written in the margins. It read: "You will never be enough." I had been devastated, feeling as though the gift had been a cruel joke. And now, as I walked through the streets, I couldn't shake the feeling that this year's gift would be no different.

The snowflakes continued to dance in the air, their delicate steps weaving a mesmerizing pattern. But I couldn't help but feel a sense of foreboding, a sense that this Christmas would be different from all the others. The gifts would come, and with them, the weight of our collective guilt and shame. And I couldn't help but wonder: what would I receive this year?

prompt: What 's on the tape ?
story: `` Is that it ? '' He sighed . `` Yeah . I hate watching these . '' `` It 's necessary . We have to know . '' Bob pushed the tape into the TV/VCR player that was all the department could afford . Up on the screen appeared a little boy , about three , clutching a teddy bear . `` Do n't . Please , not again ! '' The close ups were the worst . He reviewed it all . `` We have it . It 's all we need . '' Another day , another perp . One day , one day , we wo n't have to do this any more , thought Bob . If the medicine works , we 'll never have to do this again . He sighed , and for the last time , picked up the phone . `` Pick him up . He 's ours . '' The last man to be arrested for that hideous crime would be the first treated with the new cure .

prompt: What 's on the tape ?
story:
The old VHS player sat on the dusty shelf, its plastic casing a faded yellow that seemed to whisper secrets to the surrounding clutter. Emma's fingers danced across the worn buttons, her eyes scanning the tangled mess of cables and forgotten memories. She had inherited the player from her grandfather, a man who had spent his life collecting the detritus of forgotten eras. The VHS tapes, each one a tangible link to a bygone moment, had been his pride and joy.

As she inserted the tape, a faint hiss of static filled the air, like the quiet hum of a forgotten engine. Emma's heart quickened, her mind racing with possibilities. What was on this tape? A home movie from her childhood, perhaps, or a recording of her grandfather's favorite TV show? She had no idea.

The tape began to play, and the room was bathed in a warm, golden light. Emma's eyes adjusted, and she saw her grandfather, a young man with a mop of curly hair and a wide smile, standing in a field of wildflowers. He was holding a small, leather-bound book, its pages fluttering in the breeze.

As the tape continued to play, Emma saw her grandfather walking through the field, the book clutched tightly in his hand. He stopped at a large stone, and began to read from the book. The words were indistinguishable, but the tone was unmistakable – a low, rumbling voice that seemed to vibrate through the air.

Suddenly, the image shifted, and Emma found herself standing in a small, cluttered room. Her grandfather was sitting at a desk, his eyes fixed intently on a piece of paper. He was writing, his pen moving swiftly across the page. The words were still indistinguishable, but the emotion was clear – a sense of longing, of yearning.

As the tape continued to play, Emma saw her grandfather's hands move across the page, the words flowing onto the paper like tears. She saw him look up, his eyes locking onto something in the distance. And then, the image shifted again, and Emma found herself standing in a place she had never seen before – a place that felt both familiar and strange.

The tape ended, and the room was silent once more. Emma sat back, her heart pounding in her chest. What had she just seen? What was on the tape? She rewound the tape, and played it again, but the images remained the same. It was as if her grandfather had been trying to tell her something, but the words had been lost in the static.

As she sat there, the silence began to feel oppressive, like a weight pressing down on her chest. Emma realized that she had been given a gift – a glimpse into her grandfather's past, a window into a world that was both familiar and unknown. And as she sat there, the VHS player humming softly in the background, she knew that she would never see the world in the same way again.

prompt: Write a story that is perfectly normal , until the last line .
story: `` Aw , do n't cry my sweet little girl ! You were so quiet earlier , even with all the racket my friends made ! '' <newline> Shrill screams and crocodile tears stream from her face , unrelenting . She 's heavy . <newline> `` Oh do you have a full poopie bag ? Is that why you 're crying ? I might just have to take care of this before I can finish cleaning the living room . Such a poopie monster , are n't you . '' <newline> `` Now , where did your mommy put those clean poo holders ? '' <newline> He rummages through the shelves . Empty bottles and bottle caps . He grabs the wet naps and baby powder then turns to the closet nearby . <newline> `` There they are . Do n't worry sweet thing , you 'll be clean and tidy before you know it . I 'm a cleaner by trade , and I 'm the best . '' <newline> He sets her on the changing table and begins his dirty work . Tossing out the old diaper . Grabbing a fresh wet one and tidying up the tiny butt cheeks , covered in muck . A dash of baby powder . Then the fresh diaper , brand new . <newline> The crying dies down . <newline> `` There you are sweetheart . Nice and clean . '' <newline> He picks her up and cradles her in his arms , gently . '' he sings softly as he places her back in her crib and begins to rock her back to sleep . <newline> When the lullaby is over , he steps back to admire his work . <newline> `` No child should die screaming , `` he said as he reaches for the same gun he executed her parents with .

prompt: Write a story that is perfectly normal , until the last line .
story:
It was a typical Wednesday morning at the office. The fluorescent lights hummed overhead, casting an unforgiving glare on the rows of cubicles. The air was stale, heavy with the scent of yesterday's coffee and the faint tang of yesterday's lunch. John trudged to his desk, his feet heavy with the weight of another day's monotony.

As he settled into his chair, he noticed the clock on the wall ticking away with a steady, reassuring rhythm. It was a sound he'd grown accustomed to over the years, a reminder that time was passing, even if nothing else seemed to be changing. He began to sort through the day's emails, his fingers moving with a practiced ease as he navigated the digital landscape.

The morning wore on, a blur of meetings and reports, of pointless discussions and tedious deadlines. John's mind began to wander, his thoughts drifting to the weekend, to the freedom of a day without the weight of responsibility. He imagined himself walking through the park, feeling the sun on his skin and the wind in his hair.

As the lunch break approached, John stood up, stretching his arms over his head and arching his back. He shuffled to the break room, where he found his coworkers huddled around the coffee machine, their faces lit up by the warm glow of the afternoon sun streaming through the window.

The conversation was stilted, a series of small talk and pleasantries that seemed to hold no real meaning. John listened, his eyes scanning the room with a practiced detachment. He was a ghost, invisible and unnoticed, a mere specter haunting the office halls.

As the day drew to a close, John packed up his things and headed home, the familiar routine of the commute a comforting ritual. He walked through the front door, dropping his keys onto the counter with a soft clunk. The silence was a welcome respite, a chance to shed the skin of the office and reveal the person beneath.

And as he stood there, the darkness closing in around him like a shroud, John felt the weight of his own mortality settle upon him like a physical force. The clock on the wall, once a reassuring presence, now seemed to be counting down to his own demise. The ticking grew louder, a metronome marking the seconds until his final breath. And in that moment, John's eyes turned black as coal, and he whispered a single, chilling word: "Goodbye."

prompt: Even with all the stars on the sky , the night will always remain dark .
story: The feast had been going on for days but there was no end in sight . It was not just the celebration of two people joining each other for a lifetime of happiness , it was four decades of constant warfare coming to an end . <newline> <newline> What started as a feud between to minor leudes escalated to the most terrible war the kingdoms had seen since the dawn of men . Fourty years of murder , rape and pillaging had devastated the land and the people alike , yet the table was richly set and the wine was flowing like the blood of those who had given their life for this peace . <newline> <newline> The marriage of Emperor Aldwyn II , Lordprotecter of the realm and Earl of the Lowlands to Winifred of Princess of the mountain peak , Lady of the narrow county was truly an event to be celebrated . Aldwyn had been sceptical of his bride . He was a young man and not a too bad looking one at that . His uncle had arranged this marriage before his death as part of a peace agreement between the two kingdoms . And he was happy about the peace , no doubt . But peace at the price of his life ? There were rumors about the Princess , her father was an old man after all and her mother one of the cave people . They were not exactly renowned for their beauty and gentle souls . <newline> His concerns were washed away when her father unveiled her before the altar . She was a stunning woman with eyes in a green Aldwyn had never seen before and hair in fiery red . When her lips curled to a timid smile Aldwyn fell in love . The next three days went by in a haze . He barely slept , but he did not mind . Drunk from the wine in his cup and the woman on his lap the young Emperor danced and feasted and dined like had had not since his own father fell at the sacking of Oldtown . He swore to himself he would one day be a better father , unlike the fool that raised him . And now he had the wife who would carry his beatiful offspring , future empires of not only the Lowlands , the Shire and the moors but also the Mountains Peak and the Narrow Land . He wondered what he would name them , as their names would go down in history for eternity . <newline> <newline> But as the third day went Aldwyns lust grew . Winifred had teased him since he carried her down the stairs of the cathedral and soon he would take what was rightfully his . He grabbed her arm and pulled her close to his face . Accidentally tainting her white dress with his wine colored saliva he whispered in her ear and the two went off to his quarters . He ripped her dress in two as the door closed behind him , pushing her onto the bed . He needed this and he would take it now . <newline> As he pinned her down a thought arose in his head . This was not some whore he had picked up in an alley , fearing for her life as she complied , this was his wife . <newline> <newline> He froze for a moment , searching for something romantic to say . `` You 're not as ugly as the rumors say '' , he spat out . She seemed unimpressed . He pulled himself off her and in a moment of poetic clearness he muttered : `` You are the stars on my sky , lighting the way home . '' Caressing her face he went for a kiss and was greeted by the point of a dagger penetrating his ribs . <newline> `` Even with all the stars on the sky , the night will always remain dark . `` , she whispered in his ear . She waited for the blood to dripple out of his mouth , then shoved the Emperors lifeless body off herself . The assassin covered herself with a cloak laying near the bed and held for a moment . She had all the time in the world , her husband was not expected for another hour and with the feast going on she would have no trouble escaping . <newline> What a fool she thought to herself as she climbed past the windowframe . He was right in one way though , Princess Winifred truly is as ugly as the rumors say .

prompt: Even with all the stars on the sky , the night will always remain dark .
story:
In the velvety blackness of the night, the stars twinkled like a scattering of diamonds scattered by a mischievous hand. The sky was a deep, foreboding shade of indigo, like the color of a bruise that refused to heal. But amidst this celestial tapestry, a sense of desolation lingered, a reminder that even the most resplendent beauty can be shrouded in darkness.

Ava stood at the edge of the cliff, the wind whipping her hair into a frenzy as she gazed out at the seemingly endless expanse of darkness. The stars above seemed to mock her, their gentle sparkle a cruel reminder of the light that had long since fled. She felt small and insignificant, a speck of dust in the vast and uncaring universe.

As she stood there, the darkness began to take on a life of its own. It seeped into her bones, chilling her to the marrow. She could feel its presence, a palpable force that pressed against her skin like a cold, damp shroud. The stars above seemed to fade into the background, their light struggling to penetrate the all-encompassing darkness.

Ava's thoughts turned to her mother, who had vanished into the night many years ago. The police had given up searching for her, and Ava had been left to pick up the pieces of her shattered life. She had always felt like she was living in the shadow of her mother's disappearance, like the darkness that had consumed her was still lurking just out of sight.

As she stood there, the wind began to die down, and an unsettling silence fell over the landscape. Ava felt a presence behind her, and she turned to see a figure standing at the edge of the cliff. It was a woman, her face obscured by the shadows.

For a moment, Ava thought it was her mother, come back to reclaim her. But as she looked closer, she saw that it was just a stranger, a woman with a face that was both familiar and yet completely alien. The woman's eyes seemed to bore into Ava's soul, and she felt a jolt of recognition, like a key turning in a lock.

The woman began to move towards Ava, her footsteps echoing off the cliff face. Ava felt a sense of trepidation, like she was being drawn into a nightmare from which she might never awaken. But as the woman drew closer, Ava saw that she was holding something in her hand - a small, delicate box made of a material Ava had never seen before.

The woman opened the box, revealing a small, glowing crystal nestled in a bed of black velvet. The crystal pulsed with a soft, blue light, and Ava felt a sense of wonder wash over her. It was as if the crystal was trying to tell her something, to convey a message that only she could hear.

As the woman gazed at the crystal, Ava felt the darkness begin to recede, like a tide retreating from the shore. The stars above seemed to brighten, their light illuminating the landscape in a way that was both familiar and yet completely new. Ava realized that the night would always remain dark, but it was in the darkness that she had found a glimmer of hope, a reminder that even in the most desolate of places, there was always the possibility of light.

prompt: You dress up as the `` classic '' reaper for a Halloween party -- black robe , toy scythe , all that jazz . Midway through the night , you hear a deep , dark voice in your head ... `` I need a sick day , man , and you look like the perfect person to take my place ... Your costume is almost perfect , after all . ''
story: Death waits for no man . That 's another way of saying the vacation package was absolute shit and the dental plan left a lot to be desired . Thankfully he was able to get his shift covered and take some well deserved time off during Halloween , he did n't even have to buy a costume . He knocked on Tom 's door with a big grin on his face , which was entirely coincidental but this time his skeletal visage *meant* it . Amanda let him in with a wave of her hand . <newline> <newline> `` Tom 's in the drawing room . May I get you two something to drink ? '' <newline> <newline> `` ... ... ... .. '' <newline> <newline> `` Oh . Uh , well I 'll just grab a coffee for Tom shall I ? '' <newline> <newline> Death passed silently into the drawing room , where an overweight business intelligence consultant was pouring over scrolls crossed out with red pen . <newline> <newline> `` Should n't have survived Woodstock . Has literally no immune system . Professional ninety-year-old basejumper *oh COME ON . * You 're here , good , take a seat . Seven failed suicide attempts despite trying her best ... <newline> <newline> Death hovered uncertainly at the door until Tom 's impatient waving brought him down to a wicker deckchair . Eventually the style pen was thrown against a litany of crossed names and corrections . Tom 's eyes met the hollow pools of darkness that seemed angled slightly downwards towards the floor . <newline> <newline> `` Cinco de mayo . Explain . '' <newline> <newline> `` ... ... .. '' <newline> <newline> `` Right well I 'll tell you what it is . It 's a bloody *disgrace* is what it is . Talking to the departed ? Welcoming home the ghosts of your ancestors ? As in , what are you even *for ? * '' <newline> <newline> Death stared without comment . <newline> <newline> `` In the past two hundred years everyone 's life expectancy has been booming out of control and you do n't even have the common decency to put a stop to it . I saw a lady who was a hundred and twenty ! A hundred and *twenty ! * I had to personally apologize for the delay and might I say she was *not* happy to see me . '' <newline> <newline> Tom shuffled the papers and dumped them onto Death 's lap . <newline> <newline> `` I 've prepared your itinerary for the following year . The whole world should have entered a global warming ice age three years ago and we have a *lot* of catching up to do if we 're going to make the antibiotics shortage before June . '' <newline> <newline> `` ... ... ... . '' <newline> <newline> Death grinned .

prompt: You dress up as the `` classic '' reaper for a Halloween party -- black robe , toy scythe , all that jazz . Midway through the night , you hear a deep , dark voice in your head ... `` I need a sick day , man , and you look like the perfect person to take my place ... Your costume is almost perfect , after all . ''
story:
I adjusted the hood of my black robe, the synthetic fabric rustling softly as I checked my reflection in the mirror. The toy scythe at my side seemed to gleam with an otherworldly light, its curved blade glinting like a promise of doom. I was the epitome of the classic reaper, a harbinger of death and decay. Or so I thought.

As I made my way to the Halloween party, the sounds of laughter and music enveloped me, a cacophony of color and light that seemed to mock my somber attire. I felt like a ghost haunting the fringes of the revelry, a specter of mortality in a sea of sugar and spice.

The night wore on, and I found myself lost in the crowd, my scythe slung over my shoulder like a makeshift sword. I was a mere spectator, a spectator to the revelry, when suddenly, a voice whispered in my ear.

"I need a sick day, man," it said, the words echoing in my mind like a dark mantra. "And you look like the perfect person to take my place."

I spun around, but there was no one there. The voice seemed to come from within, a presence that lurked just beyond the edge of my perception. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized that I was not alone.

The voice spoke again, its tone dripping with malice. "Your costume is almost perfect, after all. The black robe, the scythe... you're a dead ringer for the real thing."

I tried to shake off the feeling of unease, telling myself it was just the voice of my imagination playing tricks on me. But the words lingered, echoing in my mind like a curse.

As I continued to mingle with the partygoers, I began to notice strange things. The music seemed to grow louder, the lights flashing faster and faster until they became a blur. The laughter and chatter of the crowd began to sound like a distant hum, a buzzing in my ears that made my head spin.

And then, I saw it. A figure, standing at the edge of the party, watching me with eyes that seemed to bore into my very soul. The figure was shrouded in shadows, its features indistinct, but I knew, with a certainty that chilled my blood, that it was the embodiment of the voice.

The figure began to move towards me, its pace slow and deliberate, like a specter stalking its prey. I tried to run, but my feet seemed rooted to the spot, unable to move as the figure drew closer.

The voice spoke once more, its tone dripping with malevolence. "You're not just a reaper, are you? You're the real deal. And I need you to take my place."

As the figure loomed over me, its presence filling the air with an unspeakable horror, I realized that I was not just a partygoer, but a pawn in a game of darkness and despair. And I knew, with a certainty that chilled my blood, that I was doomed to play the role of the reaper, forever trapped in a world of shadows and terror.

prompt: Over night , 90 % of the world 's population has dropped dead . In the following weeks , the survivors , who come from diverse countries , ethnicities , religious beliefs and lifestyles realize that they all share a single , peculiar trait ...
story: He was typing in a room . it had to be weeks since he heard the news of annihilation . From those that were still alive that is . This man in his mid 20 's was in a high rise apartment , a college student that you would likely know . The guy who threw the best parties , kind of dumb . Pretty average as a man scraping by in life could honestly be . An underachiever would be the hugest understatement His lisp , though held a subtlety , gave him a distinguished accent that made him sound more profound than he really was . This only added to his own charisma . Outside of parties , he stuck with friends , had some beers , and did a clockwork of '' eating , going to classes , having an obligatory 3PM cocktail right back in his dorm , , then a few of his dumb classes that he could actually pass . Afterwards , he 'd be crashing the town with his buds , getting hammered until finally passing out back in the dorm . Much of this was barely remembered , but rose-tinted eyes made the studying and maintaining a slightly average GPA worth it . <newline> <newline> The first week of the disappearance , he was in pure denial . He tried the motions of what he usually done through the day alone , minus the school . You see , where he sucked at school , he did better at at street skills . Picking locks , and being able to take whatever he needed or pleased , or inventing something.He mainly stays in his room . Power has n't gone off and Northern winters were especially cruel . <newline> <newline> By Day 4 , the Student grew curious and tired of the corpse smell he could n't fix with his Old Spice . He wanted to know how many have died , if it was something isolated . He pops right over the parking garage 's pole , jogs to his car , and busts it out to peruse around the city . All he could see for miles as he drove along the place were decaying bodies . Much of them stunk like the pits , worse than any skunk he had smelled in his life . There was some jams , which left a huge chunk of the Motor City , the business district , unable to be parsed through . <newline> <newline> He says to himself . `` I ai n't takin ' any chances . Any of them he had to cut up , to his own disgust , for the sake of convenience , were all taken into a place across the street , and kept with their bodies . Then he went back to his car , got the luggage case of his clothes and essentials , and rolls it right in there . <newline> <newline> Once he had washed up and gotten sanitized , he peruses through the kitchen . Until finally , he stumbles over the cookbook . He sat down with his laptop , opens up a YouTube video teaching him how to cook the food , and to his satisfaction , the food was phenomenal The food was the most he had eaten in a month , but to him , it felt like temporary paradise . He turns on the laptop and gets his few external drivers set up for his own media center , then binged watching a few movies , and Archer . <newline> <newline> Outside , the winds howled around all the skyscraper . The blizzard 's breeze grew harder and nastier than the night before . It gotten frostier , and the snowstorm slammed on right through . Effectively snowing himself into the high scale joint . The bodies , all aligned where they had taken their final steps , driving into poles , buildings or even plowing into people *and '' buildings , were completely neutralized . <newline> <newline> He decides to stay fore the night . Thoughts of those he had lost were no longer able to deny . He wanted to keep his mind open , but it just did n't matter . He knew for certain they were all gone . It had not . <newline> <newline> Still , the Student knew they were more worthy than him to be alive . He told himself that he was a loser , a nobody .
