God damn machine . Shit . Shit . SHIT . It was only a few days on that planet . Two god damm days . '' <newline> <newline> A tear formed and fell . It was only a couple of months more of collecting weakly radioactive material but it seemed like an eternity .

prompt: 12.000 years in the future . Civilizations fell and rose . Technology back on renaissance level . Mysterious area where no one can survive . Turns out to be Chernobyl .
story:
In the year 12242, the world was a tapestry of forgotten lore and half-remembered myths. The great civilizations that once spanned the globe had long since crumbled, leaving behind only the whispers of their grandeur. The air was thick with the whispers of the past, as if the very earth itself was a repository of ancient secrets.

Aria, a young apprentice to the esteemed Guild of Explorers, stood at the edge of the unknown, her eyes fixed on the horizon. The wind carried the scent of smoke and ash, a reminder of the countless catastrophes that had ravaged the world. Her guild had been tasked with charting the uncharted, and this mysterious region was their latest obsession.

The landscape before her was a twisted, nightmarish realm of twisted metal and concrete, as if the very fabric of the earth had been torn asunder. The ground was slick with a fine, powdery dust that seemed to cling to her skin like a shroud. Aria's companions, a ragtag group of scavengers and engineers, fanned out around her, their faces set with a mix of excitement and trepidation.

As they ventured deeper into the heart of the anomaly, the air grew thick with an otherworldly silence. The only sound was the soft crunch of their boots on the dusty ground, and the faint hum of their equipment. Aria's skin prickled with unease, as if the very land itself was watching them, waiting for them to make a wrong move.

It was then that they stumbled upon the remains of a great structure, a twisted latticework of steel and concrete that seemed to defy gravity. Aria's companions exchanged nervous glances, their eyes fixed on the entrance, a gaping maw of darkness that seemed to yawn open like a mouth.

Without a word, Aria led the way, her footsteps echoing off the walls as she descended into the depths of the anomaly. The air grew colder, the silence more oppressive, and the dust began to take on a strange, acrid scent. It was as if the very earth itself was exhaling a slow, mournful sigh.

As they delved deeper, the ruins began to take on a familiar shape, a twisted parody of a city that seemed to stretch on forever. Aria's companions exchanged awestruck glances, their eyes fixed on the twisted spires and crumbling skyscrapers that seemed to pierce the sky like shards of glass.

And then, in the heart of the city, they stumbled upon the truth. Aria's companions gasped in unison as they beheld the twisted, nightmarish landscape of Chernobyl, a city that had been frozen in time for millennia. The air was thick with the acrid scent of radiation, and the ground was slick with a fine, powdery dust that seemed to cling to their skin like a shroud.

Aria's eyes widened in horror as she gazed upon the ruins, her mind reeling with the implications. This was no natural anomaly, but a testament to the hubris and folly of humanity. The world had been warned, time and again, of the dangers of unchecked ambition, and yet they had ignored the signs, blinded by their own arrogance.

As they stood there, frozen in awe and horror, the wind began to pick up, carrying the whispers of the past on its breath. Aria's companions turned to her, their eyes filled with a mix of fear and wonder. And in that moment, they knew that they had stumbled upon something much greater than a simple anomaly - they had uncovered a piece of history, a reminder of the fragility and beauty of human existence.

prompt: A time traveller interviews major historical figures at three points in their lives : Their 16th birthday , the day after they made their most important decision , and the day before they die .
story: `` What do you want to be when you grow up ? '' Robert McCallister did n't care for the question any more than I did , but such mundane questions were necessary to sell the disguise . He was n't looking at me , he was looking through me , demonstrating his complete indifference to my presence . Of all the great kings and ruthless tyrants I 've interviewed throughout the ages , I had never felt as nervous , as intimidated , as I felt now . By a boy none-the-less ! Today I was playing school counselor for the boy that would invent the time machine . I did n't even attempt to stop him as he walked out of the office . Talking had never been one of my strong points , but this interview had crashed before it ever started . I may have failed this time , but I could n't stop my smile if I tried . Next week I 'd be there watching as he announced to the world his machine was a success ! What a day ! <newline> <newline> Today is the day ! The man who is to be my final subject , my grand finale ! Not a single open seat in the stadium , and yet there was not a whisper to be heard . How fortunate I am to have gained backstage access , and even more so , his promise of some one-on-one time . I had heard the speech a thousand times before , everyone from my timeline had . This was the day that changed the world . I had no need to be there , I had a job to do and I had to be ready . The applause resonating through the wall was enough to tell me his speech had come to a close , and my second chance was fast approaching . My tie was straight . My thoughts were clear . Pen was ready . I was prepared . But he was gone . Next week I had one more chance , one more opportunity . Next week would be this man 's last moments . I was scared . <newline> <newline> Time is a funny thing , you can see into the future or you can explore the past , but no matter how hard you tried , fate would remain fate . I 've known this day would come since I started my travels , yet I still feel so ill-prepared . It is the day the great Robert McCallister would die . A man who had seen eternity in his short 34 years , taken out by a drunk driver . here comes the truck now ! I had so much to ask , but could n't think of a thing to say . I knew it was coming . I was never good with dialogue , but I thought this time I was prepared ! There was n't much time , I had enough for a single question . I have to ask something ! `` How can a man interview his-damned-self ? ! ''

prompt: A time traveller interviews major historical figures at three points in their lives : Their 16th birthday , the day after they made their most important decision , and the day before they die .
story:
**The Weight of Time**

Lena stood before the flickering candles, her eyes locked on the figure across from her. Leonardo da Vinci, the Renaissance master, sat with an air of quiet contemplation, his hands cradling a delicate wooden cup. She had traveled back in time to his 16th birthday, a moment of unbridled curiosity and artistic fervor. The young Leonardo's eyes sparkled as he spoke of his dreams, of the machines he would build and the secrets he would unlock.

As the interview concluded, Lena felt a pang of melancholy. She had only scratched the surface of this brilliant mind. She returned to her time machine, eager to meet him again. This time, she found herself standing in the midst of a bustling workshop, the scent of oil and wood wafting through the air. The day after he made his most important decision – to dedicate his life to art, rather than engineering – Leonardo's words were laced with a sense of trepidation. He spoke of the doubts that had plagued him, of the fear that he had abandoned a promising career. Lena listened intently, sensing the weight of that choice.

The next time she met Leonardo, she found herself in a dimly lit chamber, the air thick with the scent of decay. The day before he died, his eyes sunken and his body frail, he spoke of the regrets that had haunted him. He spoke of the Mona Lisa, of the countless hours he had spent perfecting her enigmatic smile. He spoke of the love he had lost, of the friendships that had withered like autumn leaves. Lena felt a deep sense of sorrow, as if she was witnessing the unraveling of a tapestry.

As she traveled through time, Lena met other historical figures, each at a pivotal moment in their lives. She spoke with Albert Einstein, his eyes aglow with the thrill of discovery, as he pondered the mysteries of the universe. She met Frida Kahlo, her face a map of pain and beauty, as she struggled to find solace in the midst of suffering. And she met Martin Luther King Jr., his voice a powerful call to action, as he stood at the threshold of a revolution.

But it was Leonardo's story that lingered with her, a haunting reminder of the choices we make and the consequences that follow. As she stood before the candles, now extinguished, Lena felt a sense of awe at the complexity of human experience. She realized that time was not a linear progression, but a tapestry of moments, each one woven into the fabric of the past. And she knew that she would carry the weight of those moments with her, long after she returned to her own time.

The candles flickered back to life, casting a warm glow over the room. Lena smiled, knowing that she had been given a rare gift – a glimpse into the lives of those who had come before. And as she vanished into the night, she felt the weight of time settle upon her, a reminder of the power of choice and the beauty of human experience.
